description:
Organisational Change Management is the approach to managing people in a project management environment. 

In this series Jo Peacock investigates the relevance of OCM in the project environment, approaches to OCM, and impacts of under-performing OCM. 

This series will also contribute toward preparation for the PMI certification.

00:23:49.985 --> 00:23:52.710
the fact that change has gotta be managed.

437
00:23:52.710 --> 00:23:57.170
And if you are creating a new process for

438
00:23:57.170 --> 00:24:02.680
change every time you wanna implement
change, it's not particularly efficient.

439
00:24:03.980 --> 00:24:11.340
And what you need to have is a process for
change management that you can use.

440
00:24:11.340 --> 00:24:14.120
Okay, maybe with some modifications, but

441
00:24:14.120 --> 00:24:19.360
that you can use efficiently
with every new change.

442
00:24:20.900 --> 00:24:25.030
I know some people might refer to
that as being agile in concept.

443
00:24:25.030 --> 00:24:26.650
And that's exactly what it is.

444
00:24:26.650 --> 00:24:27.830
It's an agile approach.

445
00:24:27.830 --> 00:24:29.790
It's a continual improvement,

446
00:24:29.790 --> 00:24:34.700
a continual iteration approach to change
management, and an acknowledgement of

447
00:24:34.700 --> 00:24:38.510
the fact that change doesn't just
come along once every five years.

448
00:24:38.510 --> 00:24:41.420
Change is something that we have
to embrace on a continual basis.

449
00:24:42.890 --> 00:24:46.840
So when we come back, in our next episode,
what we're going to do is we're going to

450
00:24:46.840 --> 00:24:51.920
take a look at the roles that there are
within organizational change management,

451
00:24:51.920 --> 00:24:56.770
and who we need to actually
help facilitate change.

452
00:24:56.770 --> 00:24:58.558
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

453
00:24:58.558 --> 00:25:01.292
helping us understand some of
these concepts that we've been

454
00:25:01.292 --> 00:25:03.724
talking about in organizational
change management.

455
00:25:03.724 --> 00:25:07.518
Remember, that we began with just
talking about why there is change or

456
00:25:07.518 --> 00:25:08.432
what is change?

457
00:25:08.432 --> 00:25:11.369
And so Jo helped us to define that and
describe that.

458
00:25:11.369 --> 00:25:15.250
And we've discussed a little bit about the
resistance to change that's out there, and

459
00:25:15.250 --> 00:25:18.560
the importance of the buy-in
from every person that we can.

460
00:25:18.560 --> 00:25:22.600
And that's what organizational change
management is going to also help us to do.

461
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:25.960
So now it means that we need to move
forward into the concept and understand

462
00:25:25.960 --> 00:25:29.610
a little bit more about how do we drive
it and who actually drives that for us.

463
00:25:29.610 --> 00:25:32.450
And that's what we'll be seeing
in other episodes in the future.

464
00:25:32.450 --> 00:25:35.590
This is a great place for
us to go and end this episode then.

465
00:25:35.590 --> 00:25:39.550
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

466
00:25:39.550 --> 00:25:40.550
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

467
00:25:40.550 --> 00:25:41.520
>> Stay tuned right here for

468
00:25:41.520 --> 00:25:44.280
more organizational change
management episodes.

469
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:51.230
[MUSIC]

470
00:25:51.230 --> 00:25:54.374
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Exploring the roles, functions,and activities required at various management levels to effectively manage OCM.
episodes.title: Role and Activities
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:06.657
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.657 --> 00:00:08.288
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.288 --> 00:00:12.420
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.420 --> 00:00:15.090
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV,

5
00:00:15.090 --> 00:00:19.140
you're watching
the Organizational Change Management show.

6
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:22.880
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
today we're gonna be discussing roles and

7
00:00:22.880 --> 00:00:25.740
activities as we continue
through the series.

8
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:30.116
And here of course to help us out is the
organizational change baroness herself,

9
00:00:30.116 --> 00:00:33.000
Miss Jo Peacock, Jo, welcome to the show.

10
00:00:33.000 --> 00:00:34.697
>> I'm concerned actually Ronnie-
>> [LAUGH]-

11
00:00:34.697 --> 00:00:35.796
>> Did you say baroness or bareness?

12
00:00:35.796 --> 00:00:36.612
>> Baroness.

13
00:00:36.612 --> 00:00:39.926
>> Because it sounded a bit like bareness
to me and that's a little bit worrying.

14
00:00:39.926 --> 00:00:41.870
>> Yeah, baroness.

15
00:00:41.870 --> 00:00:44.100
>> I just, I thought he may have
been peeking over my fence.

16
00:00:44.100 --> 00:00:46.004
>> No, no, nope, nope, nope, not me.

17
00:00:46.004 --> 00:00:48.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so here we go Jo.

18
00:00:48.410 --> 00:00:50.050
We are now taking a look at the idea.

19
00:00:50.050 --> 00:00:53.900
We had kind of teased this a little
bit in the previous episode.

20
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:57.735
We need to talk about change management
from the perspective of whose pushing it?

21
00:00:57.735 --> 00:00:59.198
Or I shouldn't say,
that's probably not the right word, is it?

22
00:00:59.198 --> 00:01:02.645
Whose leading this idea of
change management for us?

23
00:01:02.645 --> 00:01:03.985
So, Jo, help us out here.

24
00:01:03.985 --> 00:01:06.314
>> Well, yeah,
I'm going to help, definitely.

25
00:01:06.314 --> 00:01:09.259
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Because if we're in the realms

26
00:01:09.259 --> 00:01:10.862
of somebody pushing change,

27
00:01:10.862 --> 00:01:15.110
then I can tell you now that that
change is not going to be successful.

28
00:01:15.110 --> 00:01:16.790
That's exactly what we don't want.

29
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:20.737
And I know we talked a little bit in a
previous episode about the fact that it's

30
00:01:20.737 --> 00:01:24.703
not just good enough to drag Ronnie
kicking and screaming along with change.

31
00:01:24.703 --> 00:01:30.330
We've got to, well, not just convince him,
we have got to enable him,

32
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:35.560
facilitate his understanding
that change is a good thing.

33
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:39.260
So there are lots of people involved
in organizational change management.

34
00:01:39.260 --> 00:01:43.910
If we are making a change at
organizational level, if we are bringing

35
00:01:43.910 --> 00:01:49.210
in a new project, and we're bringing in a
new service that's going to involve change

36
00:01:49.210 --> 00:01:54.240
at organizational level,
then we need to lead that change.

37
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:59.530
And we need to have a group of people
on board that is going to help us

38
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:01.160
facilitate that change.

39
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:04.110
Then like I said, it's not just about
convincing people that it's a great

40
00:02:04.110 --> 00:02:07.550
idea because convincing
them is not enough.

41
00:02:07.550 --> 00:02:09.560
We need to have people brought in.

42
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:12.280
We need to have people
willing to drive change and

43
00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:15.930
not people that are just willing to
sort of come along for the ride.

44
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:20.320
So we're thinking about what's
involved in the project, and so

45
00:02:20.320 --> 00:02:25.090
we're gonna use some PMI, Project
Management Institute guidelines here.

46
00:02:25.090 --> 00:02:30.030
And let's take a look at the activities or
rather the roles that we have

47
00:02:30.030 --> 00:02:35.000
within our PMI organizational
change project.

48
00:02:35.000 --> 00:02:39.430
And so you can see on the screen in front
of you now that we have got a number

49
00:02:39.430 --> 00:02:40.690
of roles.

50
00:02:40.690 --> 00:02:43.900
We've got our governance board and
our sponsor.

51
00:02:43.900 --> 00:02:48.020
And then underneath that, we've got our
integrators, our agents, our recipients,

52
00:02:48.020 --> 00:02:49.360
and our leads.

53
00:02:50.450 --> 00:02:52.115
Why do you think they're in blue, Ronnie?

54
00:02:53.780 --> 00:02:55.719
>> They're at a different
level than the other ones.

55
00:02:55.719 --> 00:02:56.638
>> Right.

56
00:02:56.638 --> 00:02:57.244
>> Yes.

57
00:02:57.244 --> 00:02:59.107
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

58
00:02:59.107 --> 00:03:00.827
>> That's the only thing
I can [CROSSTALK].

59
00:03:00.827 --> 00:03:01.920
>> Going for the obvious.

60
00:03:01.920 --> 00:03:02.465
>> That's right.

61
00:03:02.465 --> 00:03:04.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I'm not dumb.

62
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:05.700
I went for the honors there.

63
00:03:05.700 --> 00:03:10.200
And the very fact that they are at
the higher level in that chart

64
00:03:11.600 --> 00:03:15.650
that you have there seems to mean that
they're probably decision makers?

65
00:03:15.650 --> 00:03:17.290
>> Yeah, they're decision makers, and

66
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:20.280
actually they're less
likely to be the doers.

67
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:20.880
>> Okay.

68
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:21.930
>> And so that's the reason why.

69
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:26.970
But you're completely right, they are
the people that are at the senior level.

70
00:03:26.970 --> 00:03:30.170
They're the people that are going
to be leading the change.

71
00:03:30.170 --> 00:03:33.210
These are the people that are going to be,
you might want to consider them to be

72
00:03:33.210 --> 00:03:37.930
the figureheads as opposed to the people
that are actually doing the change.

73
00:03:37.930 --> 00:03:41.950
I wanna take a look at
the top two first of all.

74
00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:42.888
Think about governance boards.

75
00:03:42.888 --> 00:03:46.270
So who do you think should be
on the governance board, then?

76
00:03:46.270 --> 00:03:48.060
>> Well, Jo,
when it comes to the governance board,

77
00:03:48.060 --> 00:03:53.340
I would assume the project manager would
probably be on the governance board and

78
00:03:53.340 --> 00:03:56.500
then senior managers of some sort?

79
00:03:56.500 --> 00:03:58.590
>> Right.
>> Is who I would assume.

80
00:03:58.590 --> 00:04:02.688
>> Okay, but then I kind of just asked
you who the senior managers are?

81
00:04:02.688 --> 00:04:05.039
>> The senior managers-
>> [LAUGH]

82
00:04:05.039 --> 00:04:05.566
>> Who they are?

83
00:04:05.566 --> 00:04:09.940
They would be department
heads of some sort.

84
00:04:09.940 --> 00:04:12.650
People in the organization
that might lead,

85
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:15.780
maybe possibly even C level executives.

86
00:04:15.780 --> 00:04:19.872
>> Right, and the reason why I ask, and
it's not because I'm trying to be mean,

87
00:04:19.872 --> 00:04:23.445
I mean I can be, but
it's not because I'm trying to be mean.

88
00:04:23.445 --> 00:04:26.990
It's just that at some point in time,
especially if you're going through any

89
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:30.238
sort of accreditation, these are the sort
of questions that you need to consider.

90
00:04:30.238 --> 00:04:31.961
And so it's not just enough to say,

91
00:04:31.961 --> 00:04:35.243
well, the governance board are gonna
be those people that govern.

92
00:04:35.243 --> 00:04:39.493
That sounds to me to be the obvious
answer, but the people that govern may be

93
00:04:39.493 --> 00:04:44.120
different dependent on the project
that you're trying to implement.

94
00:04:44.120 --> 00:04:48.250
So the people who govern are the people
that make the decisions.

95
00:04:48.250 --> 00:04:50.650
And that's what I like to call them,
the decision makers.

96
00:04:50.650 --> 00:04:54.720
So we're gonna have somebody that's
got well, that's got the money.

97
00:04:54.720 --> 00:04:55.270
>> Right.

98
00:04:55.270 --> 00:04:58.550
>> Yeah, somebody who's
making a financial decision.

99
00:04:58.550 --> 00:05:02.750
Now that might be your CFO,
your chief financial officer or

100
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:07.410
your finance director or VP,
vice president for instance.

101
00:05:07.410 --> 00:05:09.750
It's somebody who's got the money.

102
00:05:09.750 --> 00:05:14.430
Now sometimes a customer, a business unit,
they'll quite often have money and

103
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:16.850
they might be asking for
something specific.

104
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:21.260
Or maybe it's something that happens at
sort of senior executive board level,

105
00:05:21.260 --> 00:05:23.440
depending on the scale of the project.

106
00:05:23.440 --> 00:05:26.240
So again, I'd expect to see
somebody with some financial

107
00:05:26.240 --> 00:05:28.800
responsibility on the governance board.

108
00:05:28.800 --> 00:05:32.250
I also expect to see somebody with
some technical responsibility on

109
00:05:32.250 --> 00:05:34.140
the governance board.

110
00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:37.610
Somebody who sets the strategy for

111
00:05:37.610 --> 00:05:42.440
IT, that strategy being for instance,

112
00:05:42.440 --> 00:05:47.260
whether we are moving to a Mac
environment from a Windows environment or

113
00:05:47.260 --> 00:05:50.310
whether we are remaining
with a Wndows environment.

114
00:05:50.310 --> 00:05:56.470
I think of one organization who their
major project, and their major,

115
00:05:56.470 --> 00:06:01.600
well, it was a transformational project,
was to move from a Window's based

116
00:06:01.600 --> 00:06:07.865
network in a Window's based organization
to an entirely Mac based organization.

117
00:06:07.865 --> 00:06:10.785
So there has to be somebody on that
governance board that's gonna say, yes,

118
00:06:10.785 --> 00:06:13.175
this is feasible, or no, this isn't.

119
00:06:13.175 --> 00:06:17.575
Especially, when you're talking about
a project that has that many implications,

120
00:06:17.575 --> 00:06:19.265
and has that bigger impact.

121
00:06:19.265 --> 00:06:21.450
And that's what we're talking about here.

122
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:23.820
So I'd expect to see
somebody with finance,

123
00:06:23.820 --> 00:06:27.780
I'd expect to see somebody
from a strategy perspective.

124
00:06:27.780 --> 00:06:32.820
I'd also expect to see, in conjunction
with the strategy, I mentioned technical

125
00:06:32.820 --> 00:06:38.360
ability, somebody who can actually say
whether it's physically possible or not.

126
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:41.590
Because it's not always,
when it comes to technicalities,

127
00:06:41.590 --> 00:06:44.840
it's not just about what the strategy for
IT is,

128
00:06:44.840 --> 00:06:48.640
but it's also about the fact that,
well, it needs to be possible.

129
00:06:48.640 --> 00:06:51.970
Because sometimes the environment that
we have right now doesn't allow for

130
00:06:51.970 --> 00:06:53.510
certain changes to happen,

131
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:56.320
and so we have to consider whether
it's technically feasible.

132
00:06:57.390 --> 00:07:02.100
Yes, we want the user, or
at least the customer, the person

133
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:06.420
that has influence over whether the money
is spent from the business perspective.

134
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:08.490
So that would be the requester.

135
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:11.460
I expect them to be on
the governance board.

136
00:07:11.460 --> 00:07:14.740
At some point in time during that change
and by the way, the governance board is

137
00:07:14.740 --> 00:07:18.930
not just a one-off thing that says yes,
go ahead and then that's it, walks away.

138
00:07:18.930 --> 00:07:23.820
The governance board is
a group of people who will

139
00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:27.570
require updates to the project
on regular intervals.

140
00:07:27.570 --> 00:07:30.950
So there may be a change of direction
at some point in time in the future.

141
00:07:30.950 --> 00:07:34.380
So the governance board will
make decisions on that.

142
00:07:34.380 --> 00:07:37.990
So I'm expecting somebody from
the customer environment to be there.

143
00:07:37.990 --> 00:07:41.040
I am expecting the project
manager to be there, yes.

144
00:07:41.040 --> 00:07:44.530
Because the project manager is obviously
the person that's going to manage this.

145
00:07:44.530 --> 00:07:48.550
And therefore, the project manager,
or maybe the portfolio manager, or

146
00:07:48.550 --> 00:07:53.000
program manager,
depending on the scale, that particular

147
00:07:53.000 --> 00:07:57.270
person is going to be the one that
is responsible for timelines.

148
00:07:57.270 --> 00:08:02.810
They're gonna be the person that's
responsible for the actual project itself.

149
00:08:04.470 --> 00:08:07.550
I also expect that

150
00:08:07.550 --> 00:08:12.360
you will have somebody from a support
environment on that governance board too.

151
00:08:13.990 --> 00:08:17.275
One of things that we tend to
forget in project management,

152
00:08:17.275 --> 00:08:20.560
although we tend to presume
is going to happen seamlessly

153
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:23.580
in project management is that
when we implement a change,

154
00:08:23.580 --> 00:08:28.570
when we implement something new that we
simply hand over to a support operation.

155
00:08:28.570 --> 00:08:31.160
And then that's it,
everything's gonna work absolutely great.

156
00:08:31.160 --> 00:08:31.714
Well, that's not the case.

157
00:08:31.714 --> 00:08:37.040
We want to encourage a DevOps environment.

158
00:08:37.040 --> 00:08:41.540
We want to encourage synergy
between project management and

159
00:08:41.540 --> 00:08:45.350
support environments in our
business as usual environments.

160
00:08:45.350 --> 00:08:49.340
If we're implementing change,
the only person that's really going to

161
00:08:49.340 --> 00:08:53.920
understand the level of impact is
somebody from that support environment.

162
00:08:53.920 --> 00:08:59.750
Because they're gonna understand how the
customers and the users, use the service,

163
00:08:59.750 --> 00:09:04.750
and use the IT or technology right now.

164
00:09:04.750 --> 00:09:10.869
So they are truly going to understand
how it's going to affect the users.

165
00:09:11.970 --> 00:09:16.040
So it's really important that somebody
in the support environment to be there.

166
00:09:16.040 --> 00:09:20.130
They're also the ones that are gonna
take all of the calls and potentially,

167
00:09:20.130 --> 00:09:23.920
all of the flag if something
goes wrong in that change.

168
00:09:23.920 --> 00:09:26.969
Cuz let's face it, we're in IT and
not everything goes smoothly.

169
00:09:26.969 --> 00:09:31.779
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then we've also got somebody in,

170
00:09:31.779 --> 00:09:37.070
another person in the blue here, and
that was somebody called the sponsor.

171
00:09:38.520 --> 00:09:42.810
What's the difference between
the governance board and the sponsor?

172
00:09:42.810 --> 00:09:43.680
>> [LAUGH] Of course, [LAUGH].
>> Yeah, I know,

173
00:09:43.680 --> 00:09:45.420
of course I'm gonna trick you up, right?

174
00:09:45.420 --> 00:09:47.150
I'm gonna try and trick you.

175
00:09:47.150 --> 00:09:52.110
>> All right, so, and you'll have to
correct me, cuz I may get this one wrong.

176
00:09:52.110 --> 00:09:56.480
When we talk about the idea of the
governance board and all of those people

177
00:09:56.480 --> 00:10:01.130
that make those decisions, the sponsor
normally is someone that can secure and

178
00:10:01.130 --> 00:10:06.400
also promote the actual project itself
that we need, and the change that's there.

179
00:10:06.400 --> 00:10:08.830
So they might be securing funding for us.

180
00:10:08.830 --> 00:10:13.370
Or they might be encouraging,
getting everybody else on board for

181
00:10:13.370 --> 00:10:15.360
the decisions that need to be made, and

182
00:10:15.360 --> 00:10:18.770
saying do we have that guarantee
that this is gonna be done?

183
00:10:18.770 --> 00:10:21.578
>> I like to think of
a sponsor as a driver.

184
00:10:21.578 --> 00:10:26.560
Yeah, it's a person that is going to be,
as you say, get in all of the support and

185
00:10:26.560 --> 00:10:29.100
get in all of the commitment
from everybody.

186
00:10:29.100 --> 00:10:31.780
So it's going to be a figurehead.

187
00:10:31.780 --> 00:10:33.230
I like the use of the word driver and

188
00:10:33.230 --> 00:10:35.670
I like the use of the word
figurehead as well.

189
00:10:35.670 --> 00:10:37.290
That's who a sponsor is.

190
00:10:37.290 --> 00:10:43.120
Now the sponsor's not necessarily
the project manager, because the project

191
00:10:43.120 --> 00:10:48.520
manager is somebody who is doing, whereas
a sponsor, as I've said, is a figure head.

192
00:10:48.520 --> 00:10:55.100
So I expect a sponsor to be driving,
I expect them to be visible.

193
00:10:56.420 --> 00:10:59.800
I don't expect a sponsor to

00:10:59.800 --> 00:11:03.000
I also don't expect a sponsor
to make one sort of

195

197
00:11:11.520 --> 00:11:15.810

be visible throughout the project.

198
00:11:15.810 --> 00:11:19.250

else on the governance board.

00:11:22.930 --> 00:11:27.010

202
00:11:29.880 --> 00:11:31.833

203

00:11:35.896 --> 00:11:38.380

So we talked about our blue people

00:12:30.113 --> 00:12:33.201

00:12:42.770 --> 00:12:45.640

Agents, recipients-

00:30:55.919 --> 00:30:59.016
do certain things on it but
not everything that I need.

540
00:30:59.016 --> 00:31:01.662
Because not only do I need a new watch,

541
00:31:01.662 --> 00:31:05.963
I need new eyes to go with it to
this plateau of productivity and

542
00:31:05.963 --> 00:31:10.710
this plateau productivity is really well,
where I am right now.

543
00:31:10.710 --> 00:31:12.725
And that's where I stayed as well,

544
00:31:12.725 --> 00:31:16.540
in that plateau of productivity
where it works for me.

545
00:31:16.540 --> 00:31:21.020
But it's never, ever going to meet
that peak of inflated expectation.

546
00:31:21.020 --> 00:31:25.030
So, what does that mean for us then
when we're managing change is we've got

547
00:31:25.030 --> 00:31:27.730
to be very careful with our communication.

548
00:31:27.730 --> 00:31:30.720
Otherwise, that's what ends up happening.

549
00:31:30.720 --> 00:31:35.082
And if we're not careful with our
communication, then rumors start.

550
00:31:35.082 --> 00:31:39.390
And rumors can be a good thing, but
they can also be a bad thing too.

551
00:31:39.390 --> 00:31:42.430
And the last thing we want is
a trough of disillusionment,

552
00:31:42.430 --> 00:31:47.470
the deeper that trough of disillusionment,
the worse the denial and

553
00:31:47.470 --> 00:31:51.910
the anger is when it comes to
the emotional cycle of change.

554
00:31:51.910 --> 00:31:56.330
So we want to even that out, and
if we can even this out here,

555
00:31:56.330 --> 00:32:01.160
then we can move towards evening
out the emotional cycle of change.

556
00:32:02.390 --> 00:32:07.080
So what we've looked at
are categories of change.

557
00:32:07.080 --> 00:32:11.000
And when we come back in on our next
episode, then, we're actually going to

558
00:32:11.000 --> 00:32:15.620
look in more depth at the actual change
process, the activities that we have to go

559
00:32:15.620 --> 00:32:19.660
through within organizational
change management itself.

560
00:32:19.660 --> 00:32:20.340
>> Alright, Jo.

561
00:32:20.340 --> 00:32:23.860
Once again, thank you for helping us
understand more about these different

562
00:32:23.860 --> 00:32:28.370
models of change, or the Idea of the four
changes that are mentioned in PMI.

563
00:32:28.370 --> 00:32:31.720
It really does help us to understand that
it's a part of what we have to understand

564
00:32:31.720 --> 00:32:33.500
for organizational management.

565
00:32:33.500 --> 00:32:36.710
And at the end we're
incredibly interesting here on

566
00:32:36.710 --> 00:32:39.060
the customized models that are out there.

567
00:32:39.060 --> 00:32:41.540
Cuz it really does help us to
understand a little bit more.

568
00:32:41.540 --> 00:32:45.720
The buy in seems to be more important
as Jo is actually talking on about

569
00:32:45.720 --> 00:32:47.210
the different concepts here.

570
00:32:47.210 --> 00:32:50.790
But there is more to come then, and
that means we're gonna end this episode.

571
00:32:50.790 --> 00:32:54.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

572
00:32:54.660 --> 00:32:55.552
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

573
00:32:55.552 --> 00:32:59.391
>> Stay tuned right here for more
organizational change management episodes.

574
00:32:59.391 --> 00:33:06.642
[MUSIC]

575
00:33:06.642 --> 00:33:09.669
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

1

Welcome to ITProTV.

2

>> Welcome to another great episode right

6

7
00:00:15.435 --> 00:00:18.204
You're watching organizational
change management.

8
00:00:18.204 --> 00:00:19.805
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:19.805 --> 00:00:24.118
And today we're gonna be jumping in and
taking a look at, well, corporate culture.

10
00:00:24.118 --> 00:00:27.562
And here to help us understand this
concept a bit better of course is

11
00:00:27.562 --> 00:00:30.776
committee organizational
potentate herself, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:30.776 --> 00:00:33.539
Jo, welcome back to the show,

13
00:00:33.539 --> 00:00:34.557
>> I think I was fine.

14
00:00:34.557 --> 00:00:35.188
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:35.188 --> 00:00:36.203

16

Until I don't quite understand what

17
00:00:39.246 --> 00:00:41.795
a bad thing?
>> It's an awesome thing that's because

18
00:00:41.795 --> 00:00:42.821
you are awesome Jo.

19
00:00:42.821 --> 00:00:43.836
So here we go.

20
00:00:43.836 --> 00:00:47.490
We are now taking a look at
the idea of culture, yes.

21
00:00:47.490 --> 00:00:48.749
>> I know, my head's getting bigger now.

22
00:00:48.749 --> 00:00:49.951
>> That's awesome,

23
00:00:49.951 --> 00:00:51.830
cause you deserve it, okay?

24
00:00:51.830 --> 00:00:55.300
All right, so Jo, we wanna take
a look at the idea of culture here.

25
00:00:55.300 --> 00:00:58.413
How does this fit into the idea of
organizational change management?

26
00:00:58.413 --> 00:00:59.249
>> Okay, well,

27
00:00:59.249 --> 00:01:03.570
the first thing that we've gotta accept
is that in order to make a change at

28
00:01:03.570 --> 00:01:05.870
organizational level, a big change,

29
00:01:05.870 --> 00:01:10.631
a transformational change is probably
going to involve a change in our culture.

30
00:01:10.631 --> 00:01:15.101
And so we're going to look at exactly how,
we looked in the previous episode that

31
00:01:15.101 --> 00:01:18.732
the emotional cycle of change and
how that affects individuals.

32
00:01:18.732 --> 00:01:23.467
And what we're going to look at right now
is how we can actually make that change

33
00:01:23.467 --> 00:01:25.930
happen to our organizational culture.

34
00:01:25.930 --> 00:01:29.410
If we're going to change the way
that we work as an organization,

35
00:01:29.410 --> 00:01:33.271
if we're going to implement
a transformational change, then we have to

36
00:01:33.271 --> 00:01:37.095
understand that we're gonna change
the culture of the organization.

37
00:01:37.095 --> 00:01:39.417
What do I mean by culture?
>> Yeah, so

38
00:01:39.417 --> 00:01:44.477
when we start taking a look at this
idea of culture what do we mean by it?

39
00:01:44.477 --> 00:01:47.275
Normally what I think about
of course is Language and

40
00:01:47.275 --> 00:01:51.287
customs is what I normally think about.
>> Right, okay, there's an element of

41
00:01:51.287 --> 00:01:55.028
that, you're right, because culture
is really about the way that we work.

42
00:01:55.028 --> 00:01:55.909
>> Right.

43
00:01:55.909 --> 00:01:57.479
>> It's about business as usual,

44
00:01:57.479 --> 00:01:59.692
what does business as usual look like for
us?

45
00:01:59.692 --> 00:02:03.317
And it could be about language,
it could be about time zones,

46
00:02:03.317 --> 00:02:06.533
it could be about the country
that we're in right now.

47
00:02:06.533 --> 00:02:10.017
I mean every single country
has different cultures.

48
00:02:10.017 --> 00:02:11.406
Every single country,

49
00:02:11.406 --> 00:02:15.165
every single organization has
different ways of doing things.

50
00:02:15.165 --> 00:02:18.967
There are things that are acceptable in
some organizations that aren't acceptable

51
00:02:18.967 --> 00:02:19.509
in others.

52
00:02:19.509 --> 00:02:22.201
There are things that are acceptable
in some parts of the world

53
00:02:22.201 --> 00:02:23.872
that aren't acceptable in all this.

54
00:02:23.872 --> 00:02:27.126
Some words mean different things
in some parts of the world.

55
00:02:27.126 --> 00:02:30.830
Some of the words that I use mean
something different to me than they do to

56
00:02:30.830 --> 00:02:31.843
you.
>> Sure.

57
00:02:31.843 --> 00:02:34.556
>> Yeah, I mean I go down to a petrol

58
00:02:34.556 --> 00:02:37.570
station and I fill up a petrol.
>> Yes,

59
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:40.379
I fill up with gasoline at a gas station,.

60
00:02:40.379 --> 00:02:42.066
[LAUGH]
>> I mean,

61
00:02:42.066 --> 00:02:45.130
he can't help it that he's wrong, right?
>> There you

62
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:45.728
go.
>> But

63
00:02:45.728 --> 00:02:50.323
culture is actually just about the way
that we do things, that's what culture is.

64
00:02:50.323 --> 00:02:55.353
And so
when we are implementing change we have to

65
00:02:55.353 --> 00:03:00.145
first of all understand
what our culture is.

66
00:03:00.145 --> 00:03:05.059
Culture can be something very simple
like whether we go to the gas station or

67
00:03:05.059 --> 00:03:07.480
whether we go to the petrol station.

68
00:03:07.480 --> 00:03:11.227
And that's really simple, and
I mean essentially it's the same thing,

69
00:03:11.227 --> 00:03:13.171
we just call it something different.

70
00:03:13.171 --> 00:03:17.431
But culture is all about our adaptability,
and

71
00:03:17.431 --> 00:03:23.835
about our ability to accept change,
and our ability to absorb change.

72
00:03:23.835 --> 00:03:29.531
Culture is also about our attitudes, and
about our approaches to certain things.

73
00:03:29.531 --> 00:03:33.328
Our attitudes to our customers and
our approach is to them.

74
00:03:33.328 --> 00:03:38.682
Our attitudes to the business and
how we interact with the business.

75
00:03:38.682 --> 00:03:41.385
That's all culture.

76
00:03:41.385 --> 00:03:46.314
And when we implement any transformational
change, we have to do it in a way

77
00:03:46.314 --> 00:03:51.337
that is cognizant of what our culture is,
and what we need our culture to be.

78
00:03:51.337 --> 00:03:54.412
Ultimately, I've already
mentioned in previous episodes,

79
00:03:54.412 --> 00:03:57.206
everybody is asking the question
of what's in it for me.

80
00:03:57.206 --> 00:04:00.328
And we've gotta be able to answer that.

81
00:04:00.328 --> 00:04:02.265
How is my life going to change?

82
00:04:02.265 --> 00:04:08.496
How is my culture going to change with
this particular transformational change?

83
00:04:08.496 --> 00:04:13.187
So we have something called
the change life cycle frame up.

84
00:04:13.187 --> 00:04:17.862
Now, don't be alarmed by the mess
that you might see on the slide in

85
00:04:17.862 --> 00:04:19.541
front of you right now.

86
00:04:19.541 --> 00:04:24.161
Okay, I know that it's scary but
here is the framework this came

87
00:04:24.161 --> 00:04:29.139
from the PMI from the Project
Management Institute and you will see.

88
00:04:29.139 --> 00:04:31.868
But in order to get from,
right across the top,

89
00:04:31.868 --> 00:04:36.316
from my current state to our future state,
we have to go through these steps.

90
00:04:36.316 --> 00:04:42.266
Now, to anybody who has never seen one
before, this is a project Gantt chart.

91
00:04:42.266 --> 00:04:44.602
You seen a project Gantt chart before?
>> I have.

92
00:04:44.602 --> 00:04:46.166
>> Yeah, and most people that,

93
00:04:46.166 --> 00:04:49.799
certainly, if you're studying for
any sort of PMI accreditation,

94
00:04:49.799 --> 00:04:53.070
then I'm expecting you to be
able to recognize a Gantt chart.

95
00:04:53.070 --> 00:04:56.644
If you can't, I'm gonna be
a little bit worried, all right?

96
00:04:56.644 --> 00:04:58.568
I just wanna throw that out there.

97
00:04:58.568 --> 00:05:02.032
But most people within IT should
be able to recognize this.

98
00:05:02.032 --> 00:05:05.742
And what this Gantt chart is
a set of sequential steps.

99
00:05:05.742 --> 00:05:08.942
Now, I know a lot of people that
will organize this in spreadsheets,

100
00:05:08.942 --> 00:05:11.711
that will organize this in Excel or
maybe use in MS Project.

101
00:05:11.711 --> 00:05:15.498
Or maybe other tools to
be able to display this.

102
00:05:15.498 --> 00:05:20.016
But essentially what we're looking
at is we're looking at steps.

103
00:05:20.016 --> 00:05:21.918
And over our next few episodes,

104
00:05:21.918 --> 00:05:26.222
what we're going to do is we're going
to go through each of these steps.

105
00:05:26.222 --> 00:05:29.453
We're gonna start off by
formulating the change.

106
00:05:29.453 --> 00:05:33.358
And then we're going through
planning over the change.

107
00:05:33.358 --> 00:05:37.215
And then we're going through
the implementation of the change.

108
00:05:37.215 --> 00:05:41.855
And then we're going through
the transition of the change.

109
00:05:41.855 --> 00:05:46.380
Implementation is different to transition,

110
00:05:46.380 --> 00:05:52.302
because transition is a gradual
move from the old to the new.

111
00:05:52.302 --> 00:05:55.801
The change has got to be transitioned.

112
00:05:55.801 --> 00:05:58.900
You don't just throw it over the fence.

113
00:05:58.900 --> 00:06:05.039
And I say that and I say that quite
emphatically because I hear this time and

114
00:06:05.039 --> 00:06:10.894
time again from service environments,
from support environments.

115
00:06:10.894 --> 00:06:13.411
Where they come to me and
they'll say to me, you know what?

116
00:06:13.411 --> 00:06:17.103
Our project team, they just
through things over the fence and

117
00:06:17.103 --> 00:06:19.167
then we have to pick up the pieces.

118
00:06:19.167 --> 00:06:24.524
And I hear this a lot, and I asked
one organization, not a lot long ago,

119
00:06:24.524 --> 00:06:28.649
I asked them bout how DevOps
was in that organization?

120
00:06:28.649 --> 00:06:31.716
And they said to me,
yeah it works really, really great.

121
00:06:31.716 --> 00:06:35.761
We have an excellent hand over procedure.

122
00:06:35.761 --> 00:06:40.246
That's not DevOps,
that's not a transition.

123
00:06:40.246 --> 00:06:44.750
A hand over procedure is me
giving this to Ronnie and

124
00:06:44.750 --> 00:06:51.158
saying to Ronnie there you go,
it's yours, that's not a transition.

125
00:06:51.158 --> 00:06:54.854
A transition or
a DevOps is actually me saying to Ronnie,

126
00:06:54.854 --> 00:06:57.527
here, I've got this to give to you.

127
00:06:57.527 --> 00:07:02.017
By the way, I want to draw your attention
to this, and to this, and to this.

128
00:07:02.017 --> 00:07:06.809
And if you've got any questions,
I'm gonna be right here and

129
00:07:06.809 --> 00:07:13.465
I'm gonna be answering them for you for
the first few months, that's a transition.

130
00:07:13.465 --> 00:07:17.077
There is a huge difference
between a transition and

131
00:07:17.077 --> 00:07:19.345
handover, a huge difference.

132
00:07:19.345 --> 00:07:23.493
And with any organizational change,
we don't just have a handover,

133
00:07:23.493 --> 00:07:25.473
we have to have that transition.

134
00:07:25.473 --> 00:07:30.093
You will see that the arrows
start quite early on during

135
00:07:30.093 --> 00:07:33.721
the implementation where we transition.

136
00:07:33.721 --> 00:07:36.993
The other thing that happens
right at the very bottom there,

137
00:07:36.993 --> 00:07:40.020
you've got that section that
calls sustained change.

138
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:44.437
From a previous episode, we looked at
Carter's eight steps to transformational

139
00:07:44.437 --> 00:07:47.133
change and
we talked about embedding the change.

140
00:07:47.133 --> 00:07:51.405
Well, we also call that
sustaining the change.

141
00:07:51.405 --> 00:07:56.158
In other words, the change has
to be accepted as a way of life.

142
00:07:56.158 --> 00:07:57.683
And the reason why it starts so

143
00:07:57.683 --> 00:08:01.039
early on, you'll notice that
the arrows start quite a way back,

144
00:08:01.039 --> 00:08:04.841
in fact they start at exactly the same
time as we're planning the change.

145
00:08:04.841 --> 00:08:10.690
And the reason why Is because we are
promoting the change from that moment on.

146
00:08:10.690 --> 00:08:15.235
We're promoting that we're planning
any change, we are promoting that

147
00:08:15.235 --> 00:08:19.276
there is a new change coming,
we are communicating this change.

148
00:08:19.276 --> 00:08:24.191
We're asking for feedback because
that feedback will give us buy-in.

149
00:08:24.191 --> 00:08:27.230
And if we get the buy-in from
all of our stake holders,

150
00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:30.665
from all of those that are going to be,
not just involved, but

151
00:08:30.665 --> 00:08:34.587
are going to be affected by the change,
remember those individuals.

152
00:08:34.587 --> 00:08:40.357
If we get that buy-in, then actually
it will help us to embed the change.

153
00:08:40.357 --> 00:08:47.049
It will help us to ensure that the change
is successful, and that change will stick.

154
00:08:47.049 --> 00:08:50.412
This is why things like
the emotional cycle have changed.

155
00:08:50.412 --> 00:08:55.377
This is why Carter's eight steps
to transformational change is so

156
00:08:55.377 --> 00:09:01.863
important because if we ignore the people,
the change isn't going to be successful.

157
00:09:01.863 --> 00:09:06.599
So over the next few episodes then,
what we're going to do is we're going to

158
00:09:06.599 --> 00:09:09.707
spend time looking at each
one of these sections,

159
00:09:09.707 --> 00:09:12.967
we're going to look at how
we formulate the change.

160
00:09:12.967 --> 00:09:15.868
And then how we plan for the change,

161
00:09:15.868 --> 00:09:20.529
how we implement it and
then how we transition it as well.

162
00:09:20.529 --> 00:09:22.933
As I've said, it's not just a hand over.

163
00:09:22.933 --> 00:09:27.040
And I love that arrow there,
the one that says need for time.

164
00:09:27.040 --> 00:09:29.368
It has to happen over time.

165
00:09:29.368 --> 00:09:32.281
It's not just a simple handover.

166
00:09:32.281 --> 00:09:37.367
And then, we're going to look at also,
sustaining the change,

167
00:09:37.367 --> 00:09:42.555
and how we make the change stick or
rather we make it our way of life.

168
00:09:44.669 --> 00:09:49.652
So in terms of then our next episode,
what we're going to do in our next

169
00:09:49.652 --> 00:09:54.133
episode is we're going to be
looking then at this first stage.

170
00:09:54.133 --> 00:09:57.818
And that first stage is actually
formulating their change.

171
00:09:57.818 --> 00:10:01.001
So I'm gonna invite you to come back and

172
00:10:01.001 --> 00:10:05.729
take a look at our next episode
where we launch ourselves on

173
00:10:05.729 --> 00:10:09.800
this life cycle of change.
>> All right, Jo, well, thank you for

174
00:10:09.800 --> 00:10:13.903
helping us to understand a little bit more
about the idea of what corporate culture

175
00:10:13.903 --> 00:10:16.757
means and the acceptance of
this to implement the ideas of

176
00:10:16.757 --> 00:10:18.559
change that we have to be able to do.

177
00:10:18.559 --> 00:10:21.524
And that means there is more
to come as we start taking,

178
00:10:21.524 --> 00:10:24.497
we go the process or
the life cycle of changing as well.

179
00:10:24.497 --> 00:10:26.985
So we're gonna have that for
another episode.

180
00:10:26.985 --> 00:10:31.341
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

181
00:10:31.341 --> 00:10:32.266
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

182
00:10:32.266 --> 00:10:33.316
>> Stay tuned right for

183
00:10:33.316 --> 00:10:35.856
more organizational
change management shows.

184
00:10:35.856 --> 00:10:43.376
[MUSIC]

185
00:10:43.376 --> 00:10:46.678
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

leadership.

00:05:51.170 --> 00:05:53.570
We need to have consistent sponsorship.

00:05:53.570 --> 00:05:57.090
We need to have, well,
a communication plan, regular,

00:06:02.570 --> 00:06:04.970
This is still a direction

00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:12.810

I don't mean an email every single day,
cuz trust me I'm not gonna read that and

00:06:17.470 --> 00:06:18.030
>> All right,

00:06:18.030 --> 00:06:19.230
none of us are going to do that.

00:06:19.230 --> 00:06:21.420
So when we talk about regular just think,

00:06:29.668 --> 00:06:32.813
So you know your people,

00:06:32.813 --> 00:06:34.608

00:06:34.608 --> 00:06:38.603

135
00:06:38.603 --> 00:06:41.415
So you wanna ensure

00:06:41.415 --> 00:06:47.025
which means that the leadership have

137
00:06:48.690 --> 00:06:49.810
So the next one then.

00:06:49.810 --> 00:06:51.465
If we just bring that slide back up,

00:06:51.465 --> 00:06:55.080

00:06:55.080 --> 00:06:56.960
What can I say about cultural resistance?

141
00:06:56.960 --> 00:06:59.940
Well in the previous episode,
we looked at culture.

142
00:06:59.940 --> 00:07:02.876
And we've looked at it sort of
right the way through our episodes.

143
00:07:02.876 --> 00:07:05.805
And we've looked at whether the,

144
00:07:05.805 --> 00:07:10.653
well whether the culture is
acceptable to change or not,

145
00:07:10.653 --> 00:07:15.402
or adaptable to change, or
is well able to take change.

146
00:07:15.402 --> 00:07:21.070
The cultural of an organization is really
critical in transformational change.

147
00:07:21.070 --> 00:07:23.600
If the entire cultural
is resistant to change,

148
00:07:23.600 --> 00:07:27.970
then the organization is not
going to be able to move forward.

149
00:07:29.500 --> 00:07:34.670
And I will say over and over again, that
all it takes is just one negative person.

150
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:37.590
And they can undermine
the positivity of 500 people.

151
00:07:38.950 --> 00:07:42.551
They can undermine
the success of the change.

152
00:07:42.551 --> 00:07:46.070
So what we want to nurture is
a culture within your organization.

153
00:07:46.070 --> 00:07:50.369
If you want change to be successful,
you have to nurture

154
00:07:50.369 --> 00:07:55.042
a culture where any negativity
is viewed as an opportunity.

155
00:07:55.042 --> 00:07:59.816
So where any negativity is
viewed as An opportunity for

156
00:07:59.816 --> 00:08:03.344
somebody to sit down with that person and

157
00:08:03.344 --> 00:08:09.540
to incorporate that negativity,
to overcome the negativity.

158
00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:13.582
Cultural resistance, when we think about,
and we looked at it in previous episodes.

159
00:08:13.582 --> 00:08:16.228
We think about people that
are early adopters and

160
00:08:16.228 --> 00:08:19.220
then we think about people
that are our late adopters.

161
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:22.364
And I think, what was it we called you?
>> [LAUGH]

>> [LAUGH]

00:08:24.268 --> 00:08:25.972
>> Many, many names, Jo, but

00:08:25.972 --> 00:08:28.140

00:08:28.140 --> 00:08:31.355

00:08:31.355 --> 00:08:33.728
I think that was the term, laggard.

I didn't call Ronnie a laggard, right?

00:08:36.462 --> 00:08:39.490

00:08:39.490 --> 00:08:40.039
>> It was, yeah.

170
00:08:40.039 --> 00:08:41.170
>> It was laggard, yeah,

00:08:41.170 --> 00:08:43.555
I believe.
>> Yeah, it was, but you see,

172
00:08:43.555 --> 00:08:45.669
we want to bring these people on board.
>> Right.

173
00:08:45.669 --> 00:08:46.283
>> Because,

174
00:08:46.283 --> 00:08:49.556
if we can't convince them that
something is a good idea,

175
00:08:49.556 --> 00:08:52.570
then quite simply they're
not going to be on board.

176
00:08:52.570 --> 00:08:55.443
And they could potentially be resisters.

00:08:55.443 --> 00:09:00.272
And so, we want to ensure that
the negativity of one person doesn't

00:09:00.272 --> 00:09:04.970
undermine the entire success

179
00:09:04.970 --> 00:09:06.519
When we talk about cultural resistance,

180
00:09:06.519 --> 00:09:09.497
we're not just talking about individual
people and their opinions, though.

181
00:09:09.497 --> 00:09:14.204
We're also talking about
the entire organization as well,

182
00:09:14.204 --> 00:09:18.460
and the organization may
make it difficult to change.

183
00:09:20.490 --> 00:09:23.083
If we're set in our ways as
an organization, and I mean,

184
00:09:23.083 --> 00:09:25.579
there are some organizations
that I've walked into.

185
00:09:25.579 --> 00:09:28.306
And I'll be perfectly honest with you,
if I hear the words, but

186
00:09:28.306 --> 00:09:29.870
that's the way we've always done it.

187
00:09:29.870 --> 00:09:33.870
If I hear those words one more time,
I would walk out there screaming.

188
00:09:33.870 --> 00:09:38.280
But the simple fact is that there are some
organizations where that is actually a way

189
00:09:38.280 --> 00:09:39.230
of life for them.

190
00:09:39.230 --> 00:09:42.683
But we've always done it like this,
we don't want to change this,

191
00:09:42.683 --> 00:09:46.330
we might upset people,
we've got to give them the VIP treatment.

192
00:09:46.330 --> 00:09:49.668
And therefore,
they've got to be different,

193
00:09:49.668 --> 00:09:53.624
that's all part of cultural resistance.

194
00:09:53.624 --> 00:09:54.842
We can't change what we do for

195
00:09:54.842 --> 00:09:57.150
them because we've got to
give them the VIP treatment.

196
00:09:57.150 --> 00:10:02.041
So therefore everything has got to stay
exactly the same, that, in itself,

197
00:10:02.041 --> 00:10:04.160
is part of cultural resistance.

198
00:10:04.160 --> 00:10:08.453
So that is a big barrier to change and
quite often an organization that

199
00:10:08.453 --> 00:10:13.800

actually put barriers in the way.

200
00:10:13.800 --> 00:10:16.110
And I've come across
organizations like that.

201
00:10:16.110 --> 00:10:19.290
These people are very important,
these are our VIPs and

202
00:10:19.290 --> 00:10:23.716
therefore we've got to keep
things the way that they like it.

203
00:10:23.716 --> 00:10:27.941
And that means that we've got to keep
around this old piece of technology

204
00:10:27.941 --> 00:10:30.170
because that's what they like to do.

205
00:10:30.170 --> 00:10:34.120
They like to use this,
they like the look and feel of this.

206
00:10:34.120 --> 00:10:37.380
That's a cultural resistance and
that's something that we've to get over.

207
00:10:37.380 --> 00:10:41.957
And sure, people might like,
some of your users who might consider

208
00:10:41.957 --> 00:10:45.830
themselves to be VIPs,
you may consider them to be VIPs.

209
00:10:45.830 --> 00:10:49.823
And sure they might like to use
the same thing that they've used for

210
00:10:49.823 --> 00:10:52.900
the last 20 years, but
they're also realists.

211
00:10:52.900 --> 00:10:55.722
And they understand that
the modern world has moved on, and

212
00:10:55.722 --> 00:10:58.840
they understand that technology

00:10:58.840 --> 00:11:01.810

214
00:11:01.810 --> 00:11:06.685
They're probably wondering themselves why

215
00:11:06.685 --> 00:11:09.410
technology that's out
in the big wide world.

216
00:11:10.980 --> 00:11:14.336
It happens, it happens more often
than you want to think about,

217
00:11:14.336 --> 00:11:15.900
more often than you realize.

218
00:11:15.900 --> 00:11:19.142
Where I've walked into an organization,
and they've said, but

219
00:11:19.142 --> 00:11:20.612
the users want to do it this way.

220
00:11:20.612 --> 00:11:23.503
And then when you go in and
talk to the users, they're sitting there,

221
00:11:23.503 --> 00:11:26.190
scratching their heads, thinking,

222
00:11:26.190 --> 00:11:28.727
Because I've been using
this new cell phone and

00:11:28.727 --> 00:11:30.830
I get a new cell phone every six months.

224
00:11:30.830 --> 00:11:35.220
And IT hasn't changed for the last ten
years, and I don't understand why.

225
00:11:36.780 --> 00:11:40.686
Because we make excuses for
the fact that we don't want to change,

00:11:40.686 --> 00:11:42.720
and that's a really good excuse.

227
00:11:42.720 --> 00:11:46.399

00:11:46.399 --> 00:11:50.800

00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:53.009
Yeah, I mean, that one is so

230
00:11:53.009 --> 00:11:56.930
That's the wrong way,
I want it and I want it now.

231
00:11:56.930 --> 00:12:01.009
That sounds like me, I'll be honest,

00:12:01.009 --> 00:12:02.450
I want it to happen now.

233
00:12:04.280 --> 00:12:06.508
If we allocate insufficient time,

00:12:06.508 --> 00:12:11.200

235
00:12:11.200 --> 00:12:14.476

potentially, or

00:12:14.476 --> 00:12:17.420

00:12:19.140 --> 00:12:23.594

that goes without saying,

00:12:23.594 --> 00:12:27.290
really, allocate sufficient
time to the change.

00:12:27.290 --> 00:12:33.245

240
00:12:33.245 --> 00:12:36.860

241
00:12:36.860 --> 00:12:40.460

end up with something that's poor quality,

242
00:12:40.460 --> 00:12:42.400

to be impressed by.

243
00:12:42.400 --> 00:12:45.840
And therefore they're going to be
more resistant to future change.

00:12:45.840 --> 00:12:49.257
Or we're going to end up with
something that's overpriced,

245
00:12:49.257 --> 00:12:51.040
it's going to cost us too much.

246
00:12:51.040 --> 00:12:53.406
And again, that then sets the tone for
the next change and

247
00:12:53.406 --> 00:12:55.440
people are going to be
resistant to more change.

248
00:12:55.440 --> 00:12:58.170
Because they're going to say, well,
that's going to cost us more money.

249
00:13:00.050 --> 00:13:05.037
Or we get to a point where we're rushing
things and we've just got chaos,

250
00:13:05.037 --> 00:13:07.780
but then you've also got the flip side.

251
00:13:07.780 --> 00:13:12.172
And the flip side is that if

252
00:13:12.172 --> 00:13:15.240

00:13:15.240 --> 00:13:19.683

00:13:19.683 --> 00:13:21.410
my requirements have moved on.

00:13:21.410 --> 00:13:24.610

00:13:24.610 --> 00:13:29.083

00:13:31.990 --> 00:13:35.860

00:13:35.860 --> 00:13:41.090

00:13:41.090 --> 00:13:45.316

00:13:45.316 --> 00:13:49.100

00:13:49.100 --> 00:13:53.472
Chances are the person that

00:13:53.472 --> 00:13:55.940

00:13:55.940 --> 00:13:58.962
Either that or they were tired

00:13:58.962 --> 00:14:00.810
sourced their own solution anyway.

266
00:14:00.810 --> 00:14:03.500
So get the timing right with change.

267
00:14:04.900 --> 00:14:06.330
And then let's look at

00:14:06.330 --> 00:14:10.360
So we've got here poor

00:14:21.380 --> 00:14:28.480

00:14:28.480 --> 00:14:33.130
So if you are bringing in then a new tool,

00:14:33.130 --> 00:14:36.531

00:14:36.531 --> 00:14:38.030

00:14:38.030 --> 00:14:42.406

00:14:42.406 --> 00:14:46.960

00:14:46.960 --> 00:14:50.592

00:14:50.592 --> 00:14:52.710

00:14:52.710 --> 00:14:54.150

00:14:54.150 --> 00:14:55.670
You're so focused on the process.

00:14:55.670 --> 00:14:59.137
You're so focused on what a new

00:14:59.137 --> 00:15:01.960

00:15:01.960 --> 00:15:06.427

the technology is going to be able to

00:15:26.990 --> 00:15:32.180

00:15:32.180 --> 00:15:36.410
But I've also had to make a lot of changes

00:15:36.410 --> 00:15:40.210
Because the technology

00:15:40.210 --> 00:15:45.570
I had never seen a fax machine or

294
00:15:45.570 --> 00:15:50.876
But now I find myself,
I've had people sort of asking me for

00:15:50.876 --> 00:15:55.880

00:15:55.880 --> 00:16:00.289
And so I don't have access to the right

00:16:00.289 --> 00:16:02.430

00:16:02.430 --> 00:16:07.739
And in organizations, that is so true,

00:16:07.739 --> 00:16:13.204

00:16:13.204 --> 00:16:16.640

00:16:16.640 --> 00:16:19.810

00:16:19.810 --> 00:16:22.350
But if we try and

00:16:22.350 --> 00:16:26.660

00:16:33.270 --> 00:16:35.310
So another one that we have then,

00:16:35.310 --> 00:16:38.720

not realized or

00:16:55.310 --> 00:16:55.840

00:16:57.220 --> 00:16:57.885

00:16:57.885 --> 00:16:59.310
>> [LAUGH]

00:16:59.310 --> 00:17:00.600

00:17:00.600 --> 00:17:02.070
>> Right.
>> Yes.

00:17:02.070 --> 00:17:04.050

00:17:05.100 --> 00:17:06.700
I do that all the time.

00:17:06.700 --> 00:17:10.550
I will go shopping and
not take a list, and

00:17:10.550 --> 00:17:13.621

00:17:13.621 --> 00:17:16.740

00:17:30.350 --> 00:17:34.610

00:17:50.180 --> 00:17:52.330

00:18:01.980 --> 00:18:06.622
So if you don't understand why,
then, well, like I said,

00:18:06.622 --> 00:18:09.999
you're not motivated to make that change.

00:18:11.882 --> 00:18:15.680

I mean, not in some sort of

00:18:22.370 --> 00:18:26.500

in this particular episode, yeah?

283
00:15:51.256 --> 00:15:58.590
But if you're not engaged, then how
much attention are you going to pay?

284
00:15:58.590 --> 00:16:00.017
Not very much attention at all.
>> Right, and

285
00:16:00.017 --> 00:16:03.980
it doesn't matter whether you're
responsible or not if you're not engaged.

286
00:16:03.980 --> 00:16:10.117
You see, this is why I have to know
what your influencing factor is.

287
00:16:10.117 --> 00:16:10.790
By the way, Ronnie's just

288
00:16:10.790 --> 00:16:11.372
looked at the clock.
>> Right.

289
00:16:11.372 --> 00:16:13.740
>> [LAUGH] That was hilarious.

290
00:16:13.740 --> 00:16:16.467
I have to know what your
influencing factor is.

291
00:16:16.467 --> 00:16:21.101
I want to know whether you are driving
a particular activity, whether you have

292
00:16:21.101 --> 00:16:26.160
control over a particular activity, or
if I'm just giving you responsibility.

293
00:16:26.160 --> 00:16:32.889
But actually, you could put up resistance,
because you could choose not to do it.

294
00:16:32.889 --> 00:16:35.913
So it's not just enough for
me to map out that racey John and

295
00:16:35.913 --> 00:16:38.013
to say I'm giving you responsiblity for

296
00:16:38.013 --> 00:16:41.680
something, I've also gotta check
your level of engagement as well.

297
00:16:42.735 --> 00:16:46.554
Because I could be giving you
responsibility for something that you

298
00:16:46.554 --> 00:16:49.151
might not want to undertake.
>> Right.

299
00:16:49.151 --> 00:16:50.165
>> And if I do that,

300
00:16:50.165 --> 00:16:54.400
then you're probably gonna
become a source of resistance.

301
00:16:54.400 --> 00:16:55.829
Ronnie, you've got kids.
>> I do,

302
00:16:55.829 --> 00:16:58.456
I have one.
>> Yeah, so you know what it's like when

303
00:16:58.456 --> 00:17:01.613
you give your daughter something
that she doesn't wanna do.

304
00:17:01.613 --> 00:17:02.128
>> Right,

305
00:17:02.128 --> 00:17:04.672
I do, yeah.
>> She becomes a source of

306
00:17:04.672 --> 00:17:07.659
resistance, right?
>> She's always a source of resistance in

307
00:17:07.659 --> 00:17:10.460
terms of anything that I need her to do.

308
00:17:10.460 --> 00:17:12.751
Anything she wants to do.
She's absolutely not a source

309
00:17:12.751 --> 00:17:16.463
of resistance, so I'm fine [LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] She's not always a source of

310
00:17:16.463 --> 00:17:17.013
resistance.

311
00:17:17.013 --> 00:17:18.590
She's really sweet.

312
00:17:18.590 --> 00:17:21.230
She's not always.
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

313
00:17:21.230 --> 00:17:22.780
>> But I've been there, got that t-shirt.

314
00:17:22.780 --> 00:17:27.405
And I know that sometimes they are,
but essentially, anybody could become

315
00:17:27.405 --> 00:17:28.979
a source of resistance.
>> Right.

316
00:17:28.979 --> 00:17:31.602
>> This is why, again, it goes back to got

317
00:17:31.602 --> 00:17:36.373
us eight steps in creating a need,
creating a sense of urgency and being

318
00:17:36.373 --> 00:17:41.460
able to ensure that your stakeholders
are on board with that change.

319
00:17:41.460 --> 00:17:42.860
So this is why we talk about engagement.

320
00:17:42.860 --> 00:17:45.630
It’s not just about
allocating responsibilities.

321
00:17:45.630 --> 00:17:47.371
It’s also about engagement.

322
00:17:47.371 --> 00:17:50.260
And so
that’s something that we have to achieve.

323
00:17:50.260 --> 00:17:53.210
So you asked right at the beginning
about the challenges and the resistance.

324
00:17:53.210 --> 00:17:55.364
I like to think of these
as more of achievements,

325
00:17:55.364 --> 00:17:57.370
these are the things
that we have to achieve.

326
00:17:57.370 --> 00:18:02.251
And then the other thing,
the last one on this particular slide,

327
00:18:02.251 --> 00:18:05.019
are the sponsor responsibilities.

328
00:18:05.019 --> 00:18:07.610
Do you remember who the sponsor was?

329
00:18:07.610 --> 00:18:10.987
I know that we defined it in
another episode a long time ago.

330
00:18:10.987 --> 00:18:15.139
>> The sponsor was the person that is more

331
00:18:15.139 --> 00:18:19.458
of a champion with the project?
>> Yeah I like that, yeah,

332
00:18:19.458 --> 00:18:21.530
I use the word figurehead.
>> Figurehead, yeah.

333
00:18:21.530 --> 00:18:23.469
>> Yeah, I like the word champion as well,

334
00:18:23.469 --> 00:18:24.906
that's who your sponsor is.

335
00:18:24.906 --> 00:18:27.770
So think about sponsor
responsibilities too.

336
00:18:27.770 --> 00:18:30.999
So, do you want to give
responsibilities to your sponsor?

337
00:18:32.769 --> 00:18:35.640
They might not have the time to do them.

338
00:18:35.640 --> 00:18:40.476
They might not actually have the time
to undertake any of those activities

339
00:18:40.476 --> 00:18:42.510
that you've asked them to do.

340
00:18:42.510 --> 00:18:46.442
They might not even have the time to check
whether those activities are being done,

341
00:18:46.442 --> 00:18:48.644
if they've delegated
them to somebody else.

342
00:18:48.644 --> 00:18:51.374
So think about what you
give to your sponsors and

343
00:18:51.374 --> 00:18:55.670
think about the fact that they might
not actually be able to do anything.

344
00:18:55.670 --> 00:19:00.196
And in a lot of successful change,
what we'll do is we have our sponsor, but

345
00:19:00.196 --> 00:19:03.807
the change manager whoever is
taking the leadership role for

346
00:19:03.807 --> 00:19:07.880
the change will actually maybe
perform more of the communication.

347
00:19:07.880 --> 00:19:11.422
But then send them to the sponsor,
send that email to the sponsor and

348
00:19:11.422 --> 00:19:15.024
get the sponsor to email it out or
maybe send a script to the sponsor and

349
00:19:15.024 --> 00:19:17.656
get the sponsor to record a video,
for instance.

350
00:19:17.656 --> 00:19:21.066
So think about the sponsor
responsibilities and

351
00:19:21.066 --> 00:19:25.590
think about exactly what you
want to give to your sponsor.

352
00:19:25.590 --> 00:19:29.958
And bearing in mind that the sponsor
may just be a figurehead,

353
00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.806
he may just be a champion,

354
00:19:31.806 --> 00:19:37.270
it might not necessarily be somebody
that you are going to engage with fully.

355
00:19:37.270 --> 00:19:43.477
And somebody who is going to perform
activities within that particular change.

356
00:19:43.477 --> 00:19:46.243
If I take a look at this slide
that I've got right now, and

357
00:19:46.243 --> 00:19:49.080
you'll see that we've got
different types of sponsors.

358
00:19:49.080 --> 00:19:52.680
We've got the executive sponsor who is
most definitely going to be a figurehead.

359
00:19:52.680 --> 00:19:55.143
If you're giving them
specific activities to do,

360
00:19:55.143 --> 00:19:57.910
you better make sure it's
a high level activity.

361
00:19:57.910 --> 00:20:02.293
You better make sure that you've given
them the lead and what to do, and

362
00:20:02.293 --> 00:20:07.061
you better make sure that it's something
that belongs at that level as well.

363
00:20:07.061 --> 00:20:12.760
And then you've got group sponsors at
mid-level and sort of first level.

364
00:20:12.760 --> 00:20:17.596
So when it says first level, what we
mean here are those sort of individual

365
00:20:17.596 --> 00:20:22.432
team managers, whereas you might have
your group sponsors in mid-level

366
00:20:22.432 --> 00:20:25.320
might be your sort of divisional managers.

367
00:20:25.320 --> 00:20:30.280
Accountability always goes upwards,
but responsibility comes downwards.

368
00:20:30.280 --> 00:20:34.164
In other words, if you're the executive
sponsor, you're going to delegate, but

369
00:20:34.164 --> 00:20:35.380
you will take ownership.

370
00:20:35.380 --> 00:20:40.361
Ownership always belongs at the senior
level, but the responsibility,

371
00:20:40.361 --> 00:20:44.550
it generally filters down to
the lower levels of management.

372
00:20:46.460 --> 00:20:51.297
Irrespective of who your sponsors are,
we have to make sure that

373
00:20:51.297 --> 00:20:56.060
you have given the right sets
of activities to those sponsors.

374
00:20:56.060 --> 00:21:00.968
And as I've already said,
don't give your senior sponsors something

375
00:21:00.968 --> 00:21:04.250
to do that they're not
going to want to take.

376
00:21:04.250 --> 00:21:07.675
Because again, they're human,
exactly the same as Ronnie,

377
00:21:07.675 --> 00:21:09.170
is exactly the same as I am.

378
00:21:09.170 --> 00:21:13.241
If you give me something that I don't want
to do, then I'm going to become a source

379
00:21:13.241 --> 00:21:16.080
of resistance,
just like Ronnie's daughter, right?

380
00:21:17.450 --> 00:21:22.161
So what we've done in this particular
episode is, we have looked at challenges,

381
00:21:22.161 --> 00:21:26.420
or I like to call them achievements,
cuz I want to be positive about this.

382
00:21:26.420 --> 00:21:28.330
So we've looked at the achievements.

383
00:21:28.330 --> 00:21:32.016
What it is we've really
got to insure happens to

384
00:21:32.016 --> 00:21:36.177
enable transformational
success with our changes.

385
00:21:36.177 --> 00:21:39.627
So, on our next episode,
when you join us again,

386
00:21:39.627 --> 00:21:44.540
we are going to look at change
management at the portfolio level.

387
00:21:44.540 --> 00:21:46.626
And we're going to run
the next few episodes,

388
00:21:46.626 --> 00:21:48.830
we're going to look at
Portfolio level change.

389
00:21:48.830 --> 00:21:52.475
We're going to look at Program level
change, and we're going to look at

390
00:21:52.475 --> 00:21:57.398
specific project-level change as well.
>> All right, Jo, thank you for helping

391
00:21:57.398 --> 00:22:01.346
us to understand more of this idea of the
challenges that we definitely have to meet

392
00:22:01.346 --> 00:22:05.427
and overcome, if we're going to implement
some type of transformational change.

393
00:22:05.427 --> 00:22:08.066
The very fact is,
there's no bypass to this,

394
00:22:08.066 --> 00:22:10.600
we can't hop over any of these things.

395
00:22:10.600 --> 00:22:12.943
It's very important that
we encounter each one, and

396
00:22:12.943 --> 00:22:16.239
that we overcome them to help us to
achieve the level of change that we want.

397
00:22:16.239 --> 00:22:20.730
There is more to come in Organizational
Change, but that is for another episode.

398
00:22:20.730 --> 00:22:25.361
So signing off for IT ProTV, I’m your
host Ronnie Wong and I’m Jo Peacock.

399
00:22:25.361 --> 00:22:29.660
Stay tuned right here for more of the
Organizational Change Management episodes.

400
00:22:29.660 --> 00:22:36.470
[MUSIC]

401
00:22:36.470 --> 00:22:40.497
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

00:02:57.785 --> 00:03:01.043

00:03:01.043 --> 00:03:03.550

00:04:57.980 --> 00:05:00.556

within the organization.

00:05:00.556 --> 00:05:06.720
So it sits there as a project with a low
priority in this portfolio that you see.

00:05:24.575 --> 00:05:28.704
What projects we are gonna remove,
if we do remove any and

00:05:28.704 --> 00:05:32.500

those projects as well.

101
00:05:32.500 --> 00:05:35.661
These projects that we have in our

00:05:35.661 --> 00:05:39.217
as you can see in front of you,
they're not necessarily interdependent or

00:05:39.217 --> 00:05:41.020
even related at all.

00:05:41.020 --> 00:05:47.672
So, it can be very difficult then to
prioritize all of these projects.

00:05:47.672 --> 00:05:51.683
Because you may have a project for
a particular business user,

you may have a subportfolio with
programs in a linked project for

107
00:05:55.770 --> 00:05:58.830
another particular business unit.

108
00:05:58.830 --> 00:06:03.666
You may have a project that the marketing
team have requested because they

We don't even do that necessarily
at the program level.

341
00:20:42.968 --> 00:20:45.108
We plan changes at the program level, but

342
00:20:45.108 --> 00:20:48.118
we certainly don't implement
them at the program level.

343
00:20:48.118 --> 00:20:52.658
So what we're concerned with right now,
then, is at portfolio level,

344
00:20:52.658 --> 00:20:54.448
we're concerned with this.

345
00:20:54.448 --> 00:20:58.428
We're concerned with ensuring
that whatever it is we

346
00:20:58.428 --> 00:21:03.720
implement into the live
environment is accepted.

347
00:21:03.720 --> 00:21:07.690
We use the term embedded in IT,
and I quite like that, but

348
00:21:07.690 --> 00:21:11.870
I also like the term accepted and
followed as well, yeah.

349
00:21:11.870 --> 00:21:14.986
You want to make it difficult to go back,
but

350
00:21:14.986 --> 00:21:18.010
we've already talked about
this in previous episodes.

351
00:21:18.010 --> 00:21:21.250
This is not just about removing
the old way of doing things.

352
00:21:21.250 --> 00:21:24.900
This is actually about, well,
creating that sense of urgency,

353
00:21:24.900 --> 00:21:29.040
creating a need so
other people don't want to go back.

354
00:21:29.040 --> 00:21:33.070
Now I know that this is a common theme
[LAUGH] throughout this particular series.

355
00:21:33.070 --> 00:21:38.162
But we want to give Ronnie a TV that is so
great and so spectacular that he never,

356
00:21:38.162 --> 00:21:43.272
ever wants to turn on that wooden console
box that's in the corner of the room.

357
00:21:43.272 --> 00:21:44.932
>> [LAUGH]

358
00:21:44.932 --> 00:21:46.467
>> It's never gonna happen, I know,

359
00:21:46.467 --> 00:21:47.730
I know him.
>> [LAUGH]

360
00:21:47.730 --> 00:21:50.290
>> But I'm trying here, I am trying.

361
00:21:51.670 --> 00:21:55.995
Benefits realizations starts
as soon as the assessment,

362
00:21:55.995 --> 00:21:59.974
that readiness, is agreed and
the scope is defined.

363
00:22:01.553 --> 00:22:02.528
Do you know why?

364
00:22:02.528 --> 00:22:06.770
That's quite an interesting point,
and I really like that point.

365
00:22:06.770 --> 00:22:10.880
And it's something that we forget,
do have any idea why?

366
00:22:11.940 --> 00:22:13.813
It's something that's
quite often overlooked

367
00:22:13.813 --> 00:22:14.429
>> No I don't,

368
00:22:14.429 --> 00:22:15.773
as I start to think about it,

369
00:22:15.773 --> 00:22:19.200
I'm not sure why.
>> I wanna make sure that you're

370
00:22:19.200 --> 00:22:19.840
ready for this.

371
00:22:19.840 --> 00:22:23.726
There is absolutely, it goes back to
what I was saying previously about

372
00:22:23.726 --> 00:22:25.942
these e-book readers, for instance.

373
00:22:25.942 --> 00:22:28.730
I wanna make sure that
the marketplace is ready.

374
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:35.130
So I'm gonna start embedding the change
whilst I'm still formulating the change.

375
00:22:35.130 --> 00:22:38.690
Because, you see,
if I don't think that you're ready for

376
00:22:38.690 --> 00:22:44.280
a new TV, if I don't start preparing
you for a new TV, then there's

377
00:22:44.280 --> 00:22:47.750
absolutely no way on this earth that
you're gonna use it if I give it to you.

378
00:22:49.030 --> 00:22:51.640
So my change is gonna be unsuccessful.

379
00:22:51.640 --> 00:22:53.984
It's not going to work.

380
00:22:53.984 --> 00:22:56.301
You're gonna go back to your old ways of

381
00:22:56.301 --> 00:22:59.900
working.
>> Agreed.

382
00:22:59.900 --> 00:23:01.180
>> And so what we've gotta do

383
00:23:01.180 --> 00:23:02.260
is we've got to prepare.

384
00:23:02.260 --> 00:23:05.050
Remember what we said in
previous episodes about,

385
00:23:05.050 --> 00:23:09.590
in organizational change, we've got to
ensure that we create a sense of urgency.

386
00:23:09.590 --> 00:23:12.530
That we've got to create a need.

387
00:23:12.530 --> 00:23:18.492
And therefore, benefits realization
has got to start from the moment that

388
00:23:18.492 --> 00:23:25.130
we formulate the plan for any particular
change, and for any particular project.

389
00:23:25.130 --> 00:23:28.510
I've gotta make sure that I
can articulate the benefits.

390
00:23:28.510 --> 00:23:31.505
Remember the positives gotta
outweigh the negative?

391
00:23:31.505 --> 00:23:34.660
I've gotta articulate to you from day one.

392
00:23:35.970 --> 00:23:37.710
You're not going to start and

393
00:23:37.710 --> 00:23:43.160
use this new TV if I cannot articulate
to you what the benefits will be.

394
00:23:43.160 --> 00:23:48.057
And I have got to ask you, from day one,
whether you see this being

395
00:23:48.057 --> 00:23:52.262
of a benefit to you,
whether you would actually use it.

396
00:23:52.262 --> 00:23:57.126
Cuz if you wouldn't use something, then
why am I spending potentially millions of

397
00:23:57.126 --> 00:24:01.290
dollars or pounds Creating something
that you are not going to use.

398
00:24:01.290 --> 00:24:02.528
>> Right.

399
00:24:02.528 --> 00:24:05.713
>> So benefits realization is not just

400
00:24:05.713 --> 00:24:06.660
a case.

401
00:24:06.660 --> 00:24:10.380
And this is where many projects fail,
because they fail to.

402
00:24:10.380 --> 00:24:13.660
Well, the projects themselves
don't necessarily fail, but

403
00:24:13.660 --> 00:24:18.070
we fail to articulate that ROI,
that return on investment.

404
00:24:18.070 --> 00:24:20.450
Or even the VOI, the value on investment,

405
00:24:20.450 --> 00:24:25.010
because we don't really understand
what the true value is.

406
00:24:25.010 --> 00:24:26.830
So we have to work out,

407
00:24:26.830 --> 00:24:31.220
right from the very beginning,
what the benefit should look like.

408
00:24:31.220 --> 00:24:35.110
And then once the project has been
implemented, then I come back to you and

409
00:24:35.110 --> 00:24:40.220
I say, okay then, did you get
the benefits that I promised you would?

410
00:24:41.220 --> 00:24:45.220
And what I'm hoping for at that point
is that you're gonna say to me,

411
00:24:45.220 --> 00:24:49.320
actually yes, Jo I got them,
and I got so much more.

412
00:24:49.320 --> 00:24:53.150
In other words,
here I've got you a new TV and

413
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:58.400
I'm going to plan this new TV,
I'm going to build it with you in mind.

414
00:24:58.400 --> 00:25:02.060
And I'm going to sell you on the benefits
of that new TV, and then I'm gonna

415
00:25:02.060 --> 00:25:06.030
come back to you and I'm gonna say, did
you get everything that I promised you?

416
00:25:06.030 --> 00:25:08.850
Did you get everything that you asked for?

417
00:25:08.850 --> 00:25:11.128
Do you perceive it to be value for money?

418
00:25:11.128 --> 00:25:14.950
And you're gonna say to me,
I got everything that I asked for and so

419
00:25:14.950 --> 00:25:15.480
much more.

420
00:25:16.650 --> 00:25:19.010
And that's what I want from you.

421
00:25:19.010 --> 00:25:20.760
That's exactly what I want from you.

422
00:25:22.050 --> 00:25:29.402
So this is what we have to do then
at this strategic portfolio level.

423
00:25:29.402 --> 00:25:31.880
I mean, portfolio change management,

424
00:25:31.880 --> 00:25:37.150
what we're doing is well,
we are making strategic decisions.

425
00:25:37.150 --> 00:25:39.720
We are the, well, the main,

426
00:25:39.720 --> 00:25:44.740
it says that the primary conduit between
managers of the portfolio components.

427
00:25:44.740 --> 00:25:49.747
But we are the people that will
coordinate all of the projects and

428
00:25:49.747 --> 00:25:54.105
all of the programs,
to ensure that we are prioritizing

429
00:25:54.105 --> 00:25:58.113
the projects in a way that is best for
the business.

430
00:25:58.113 --> 00:26:00.816
And of course we're also
the people that are, well,

431
00:26:00.816 --> 00:26:04.130
assigning all the responsibility for
all of those projects too.

432
00:26:05.700 --> 00:26:10.528
So in this particular episode what we have
looked at is we've looked at strategic

433
00:26:10.528 --> 00:26:11.960
decision making.

434
00:26:11.960 --> 00:26:17.380
We've looked at managing the decision as
to whether to go ahead with the change.

435
00:26:17.380 --> 00:26:19.890
And in our next episode,
then we're going to look at this

436
00:26:19.890 --> 00:26:24.834
from the program management perspective.
>> All right Jo, well, thank you for

437
00:26:24.834 --> 00:26:27.212
helping us to focus in on
this idea of strategy.

438
00:26:27.212 --> 00:26:29.608
It's missed most of the,
I won't say most of the time.

439
00:26:29.608 --> 00:26:33.967
It's missed often when we start to
actually take a look at the very fact that

440
00:26:33.967 --> 00:26:37.000
we focus in on projects and
not the strategy.

441
00:26:37.000 --> 00:26:41.950
And we'd only do that, we start
only seeing incremental changes and

442
00:26:41.950 --> 00:26:45.740
not the full benefit of all the changes
that Jo has been talking about.

443
00:26:45.740 --> 00:26:49.183
So we wanna make sure that we understand
that in organizational change management,

444
00:26:49.183 --> 00:26:50.750
it is a change of everything.

445
00:26:50.750 --> 00:26:53.830
It has to begin at the strategic
level if we are going to do this.

446
00:26:53.830 --> 00:26:56.021
So in this episode we did see quite a bit,
but

447
00:26:56.021 --> 00:26:58.803
there is more to come as Jo
has been teasing us about now,

448
00:26:58.803 --> 00:27:03.086
that just didn't last minute or two, so
we're gonna save that for another episode.

449
00:27:03.086 --> 00:27:06.970
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

450
00:27:06.970 --> 00:27:07.970
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

451
00:27:07.970 --> 00:27:09.976
>> Stay tuned right here for

452
00:27:09.976 --> 00:27:13.993
more organizational change
management episodes

00:27:13.993 --> 00:27:19.286
[MUSIC]

00:27:19.286 --> 00:27:22.042
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.376
Welcome to ITPro.TV,

2
00:00:03.376 --> 00:00:06.509
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
