4
00:00:08.214 --> 00:00:13.075
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome to another

5
00:00:13.075 --> 00:00:15.010
great episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.010 --> 00:00:18.890
You're watching
the Organizational Change Management Show.

7
00:00:18.890 --> 00:00:20.200
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

8
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:24.210
today, we're gonna be focusing
on program change management.

9
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:25.570
And who better to help us out,

10
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:30.175
of course, than the change management
premiere herself, it's Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:30.175 --> 00:00:31.980
Jo, welcome to the show,
how are you doing?

12
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:32.920
>> Thank you for having me.

13
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:35.250
Ronnie, how are you?
>> I am doing well, Jo,

14
00:00:35.250 --> 00:00:40.730
as we continue on in taking a look at the
idea of organizational change management.

15
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:44.350
We've previously discussed a little
bit about strategic change management

16
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:45.140
of course.

17
00:00:45.140 --> 00:00:48.200
And then, portfolio change management,
I should say.

18
00:00:48.200 --> 00:00:51.920
And then, now we're taking a look
at program change management.

19
00:00:51.920 --> 00:00:55.302
So where is this leading us?
>> Well, before we go any further,

20
00:00:55.302 --> 00:00:57.949
what I want to do is just
refresh everybody's mind.

21
00:00:57.949 --> 00:00:58.760
>> Sounds good.

22
00:00:58.760 --> 00:01:01.568
>> Just on what the difference between

23
00:01:01.568 --> 00:01:07.931
a portfolio and a project, and a program
is because that's obviously, well and

24
00:01:07.931 --> 00:01:14.220
I know I said in previous episodes that,
a portfolio, program, project.

25
00:01:14.220 --> 00:01:17.035
These are terms that
are used interchangeably.

26
00:01:17.035 --> 00:01:19.855
And these are obviously confusing terms,
I think.

27
00:01:19.855 --> 00:01:22.565
And so I just wanna refresh your memories.

28
00:01:22.565 --> 00:01:26.990
And just bring up this quick little
graphic on the screen in front of you now,

29
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:31.785
just to show you the difference between
a portfolio and the program and a project.

30
00:01:31.785 --> 00:01:36.760
A portfolio, well I've already
said this is your data source for

31
00:01:36.760 --> 00:01:39.842
all of your projects and your programs.

32
00:01:41.062 --> 00:01:47.290
A program is a set of connected projects,
so they are related in some way.

33
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:53.500
They may well be to do with
the same service, they may well

34
00:01:53.500 --> 00:01:57.860
be to do with the same hardware, or they
may well be for the same business unit.

35
00:01:57.860 --> 00:02:03.200
So a program is a set of projects
that are related in some way.

36
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:07.070
Sometimes though projects
are just a one of project for

37
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:11.690
a particular business unit or
for a particular service or

38
00:02:11.690 --> 00:02:14.610
a particular piece of hardware,
for instance.

39
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:17.030
In which case then, that would just be and

40
00:02:17.030 --> 00:02:20.370
individual project as we got in
the middle there in the green.

41
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:25.300
In portfolio management just manages
all of those to make sure that we have

42
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:28.020
The right number of projects and

43
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:32.010
that we have the right
prioritization on those projects.

44
00:02:32.010 --> 00:02:36.830
And project management,
well, projects are managed

45
00:02:36.830 --> 00:02:41.890
individually to be released as
changes into the live environment.

46
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:46.250
So that's just a real quick recap on
the difference between a project and

47
00:02:46.250 --> 00:02:49.150
a program and a portfolio.

48
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:52.370
And so here we are in our last series,
our last episode,

49
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:56.880
we looked at portfolio management.

50
00:02:56.880 --> 00:02:58.267
I'm just trying get my right slide up

51
00:02:58.267 --> 00:02:58.920
here.
>> [LAUGH]

52
00:02:58.920 --> 00:02:59.820
>> In the last show,

53
00:02:59.820 --> 00:03:04.240
we looked at portfolio management,
and what we're interested in portfolio

54
00:03:04.240 --> 00:03:09.240
management is actually managing
the formulation of the change.

55
00:03:09.240 --> 00:03:12.310
It's managing the idea for
a particular project.

56
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:15.820
What it is, well prioritizing that idea,

57
00:03:15.820 --> 00:03:21.030
managing that idea and
also well agreeing on that idea as well.

58
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:25.600
So deciding whether we're going to
implement a specific project or not and

59
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:30.060
prioritizing that and
ensuring we've got the right time and

60
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:34.180
the right money and the right resources
to be able to deliver a project.

61
00:03:34.180 --> 00:03:37.530
So, here we are then
at program management.

62
00:03:37.530 --> 00:03:41.710
Now remember,
a program is a set of related projects.

63
00:03:42.910 --> 00:03:47.760
So, we are still in this top left-hand

64
00:03:47.760 --> 00:03:52.250
corner where it says formulate change,
believe it or not we're still here.

65
00:03:53.270 --> 00:03:56.550
Because you see at the portfolio
level at this very top level,

66
00:03:56.550 --> 00:03:58.920
they are prioritizing the projects.

67
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:05.475
But here in program level,
what we're doing is we're looking at our

68
00:04:05.475 --> 00:04:11.370
interrelated projects, and we're saying,
okay, where are our commonalities?

69
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:15.660
Where are our resources
going to be needed and when?

70
00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:18.880
We're looking at
coordinating the hardware.

71
00:04:18.880 --> 00:04:22.710
We're looking at coordinating
the resources, making sure that we've got

72
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:27.040
the right amount of money to
be spent on the right project.

73
00:04:27.040 --> 00:04:31.150
Because the first project in
a series of projects were,

74
00:04:31.150 --> 00:04:35.480
that might cost more money than the last
one, or it might be the other way around.

75
00:04:35.480 --> 00:04:37.420
So here at program management, then,

76
00:04:37.420 --> 00:04:40.750
we are doing the coordination
across all of the projects.

77
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:46.799
The other thing about program
management is that with a program,

78
00:04:46.799 --> 00:04:51.718
we may be in a position where we
cannot realize the full benefit of any

79
00:04:51.718 --> 00:04:55.363
change until we've released
all of the changes.

80
00:04:55.363 --> 00:04:59.020
In other words,
until we've released all of the projects.

81
00:04:59.020 --> 00:05:03.676
And when you think about Agile,
and in an Agile environment,

82
00:05:03.676 --> 00:05:07.200
we release on an incremental basis.

83
00:05:07.200 --> 00:05:11.865
So if you think of the program management
role then as being the role that

84
00:05:11.865 --> 00:05:15.760
coordinate every individual
sort of iteration,

85
00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:20.690
every release if you were, so
in other words, every individual project.

86
00:05:20.690 --> 00:05:23.360
So we’re still here,
at this formulating the change,

87
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:26.335
because here we’re planning the change.

88
00:05:26.335 --> 00:05:30.225
What I expect program management
to be doing at this point is,

89
00:05:30.225 --> 00:05:34.775
I expect program management to be
evaluating every single project

90
00:05:34.775 --> 00:05:39.805
that is within a group of projects,
within that particular program.

91
00:05:39.805 --> 00:05:44.425
And I expect them to be feeding back to
portfolio management on the prioritization

92
00:05:44.425 --> 00:05:46.070
of any given project.

93
00:05:46.070 --> 00:05:48.130
And the feasibility of any given project.

94
00:05:48.130 --> 00:05:51.900
And also,
the deliverable of any given project too.

95
00:05:51.900 --> 00:05:53.540
There may be interdependencies.

96
00:05:54.780 --> 00:05:57.430
If they're related, there probably
is gonna be interdependencies.

97
00:05:57.430 --> 00:06:02.210
And it might be interdependencies,
we can't do this until we've done that.

98
00:06:02.210 --> 00:06:05.330
Or it may be, well, actually,
I can't use Ronnie on two things.

99
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:08.240
So, Ronnie's got to finish this
first before he can then move

100
00:06:08.240 --> 00:06:11.680
over to this project and
work on this particular task.

101
00:06:11.680 --> 00:06:16.500
So, program management is going to feed
that back to portfolio management,

102
00:06:16.500 --> 00:06:19.050
because portfolio management
are prioritizing.

103
00:06:20.200 --> 00:06:24.930
So what program management are doing,
well they're managing the program and

104
00:06:24.930 --> 00:06:27.755
they are managing the resources
across the program.

105
00:06:27.755 --> 00:06:32.130
But portfolio management will
be making the decisions, and

106
00:06:32.130 --> 00:06:34.200
they will be prioritizing.

107
00:06:34.200 --> 00:06:35.920
They are at strategy level.

108
00:06:35.920 --> 00:06:40.322
So think of program management
as being at a tactical level.

109
00:06:40.322 --> 00:06:44.910
So they're managing across
each individual project.

110
00:06:44.910 --> 00:06:48.250
So our next graphic here,
is actually quite a good graphic.

111
00:06:48.250 --> 00:06:54.040
Because you see as far as the program is
concerned, what they're interested in

112
00:06:54.040 --> 00:06:59.760
the program management is the definition
of the program, is that group of projects.

113
00:07:01.010 --> 00:07:06.930
Then, the delivery of the benefits of
the group of projects in its entirety.

114
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:13.270
And then the closing of the group of
projects, again in their entirety.

343
00:21:39.600 --> 00:21:42.930
I've already mentioned the RACI chart,
okay, the responsible, accountable,

344
00:21:42.930 --> 00:21:44.330
consulted, and informed.

345
00:21:45.460 --> 00:21:48.010
We need to plan for
how we're going to integrate and

346
00:21:48.010 --> 00:21:50.700
how we're going to
engage our stakeholders.

347
00:21:50.700 --> 00:21:54.830
We need to plan for
the communication with our stakeholders.

348
00:21:54.830 --> 00:21:56.710
At what level are we communicating?

349
00:21:56.710 --> 00:21:59.440
And what exactly are we communicating?

350
00:21:59.440 --> 00:22:06.050
And then what we're expecting from them
throughout the actual project itself.

351
00:22:06.050 --> 00:22:11.350
You will notice that what we're doing
right now is we are talking about planning

352
00:22:11.350 --> 00:22:15.540
and that's what we've done, is we've
talked about planning up until now.

353
00:22:15.540 --> 00:22:18.240
Because at program level,

354
00:22:18.240 --> 00:22:22.080
we've got to do a lot more planning
than you might actually think.

355
00:22:22.080 --> 00:22:25.870
Because when it comes to
bringing in stakeholders,

356
00:22:25.870 --> 00:22:29.940
these are stakeholders probably for
that entire suite of projects,

357
00:22:29.940 --> 00:22:32.780
which means that their involvement
level may be quite high.

358
00:22:33.940 --> 00:22:39.564
How many people from the organization
do you know that want to get involved

359
00:22:39.564 --> 00:22:44.471
at a detailed level in every
single project that you're doing?

360
00:22:44.471 --> 00:22:46.151
You've got to get them involved and

361
00:22:46.151 --> 00:22:48.620
you've got to get them
involved at the right level.

362
00:22:49.780 --> 00:22:53.130
I don't know many people within an
organization that's got 100% of their time

363
00:22:53.130 --> 00:22:55.370
to dedicate to our project.

364
00:22:55.370 --> 00:23:00.120
So I mean, I know that we've got some
pretty good people within the business.

365
00:23:00.120 --> 00:23:02.480
But, nevertheless,

366
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:06.790
what the business wants is to be the
recipients of the benefits of the change.

367
00:23:08.220 --> 00:23:12.210
And so this is why it's important that
this is done in program level and

368
00:23:12.210 --> 00:23:13.300
not at project level.

369
00:23:14.360 --> 00:23:19.480
Cuz can you imagine how
irritated you'd be if I was

370
00:23:19.480 --> 00:23:23.400
implementing a project, and I asked you,
okay, Ronny, can I have an hour a week?

371
00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:25.258
And you'd say to me-
>> Yeah.

372
00:23:25.258 --> 00:23:25.990
>> Hopefully, yeah?

373
00:23:25.990 --> 00:23:30.860
Good, but then, if Cherokee came and
ask you for an hour a week.

374
00:23:30.860 --> 00:23:31.580
>> Never.

375
00:23:31.580 --> 00:23:32.908
>> Never [LAUGH].

376
00:23:32.908 --> 00:23:34.459
>> Of course, of course I would, yeah.

377
00:23:34.459 --> 00:23:35.069
>> No, you would,

378
00:23:35.069 --> 00:23:36.080
you would.
>> I would.

379
00:23:36.080 --> 00:23:36.878
>> And then, Wes came and

380
00:23:36.878 --> 00:23:38.634
asked you for an hour a week.
>> I would do it.

381
00:23:38.634 --> 00:23:40.069
>> Right, and then Daniel came and

382
00:23:40.069 --> 00:23:42.230
asked you for an hour a week.
>> I would do it.

383
00:23:42.230 --> 00:23:43.009
>> And Justin came and

384
00:23:43.009 --> 00:23:44.860
asked you for an hour a week.
>> I would do it.

385
00:23:44.860 --> 00:23:46.990
>> All of a sudden though, you've

386
00:23:46.990 --> 00:23:50.200
just used up six hours of your week.
>> I know.

387
00:23:50.200 --> 00:23:53.196
>> Right, now you might be really really

388
00:23:53.196 --> 00:23:57.370
generous, but not everybody's like that.
>> Right.

389
00:23:57.370 --> 00:23:58.942
>> Which is why we've gotta do this at

390
00:23:58.942 --> 00:23:59.871
the program level.

391
00:23:59.871 --> 00:24:05.132
This is why, and in it's very simplest
form, It's no good me coming to you and

392
00:24:05.132 --> 00:24:10.154
asking you for a week, and then Cherokee,
and then Wes, and then Justin,

393
00:24:10.154 --> 00:24:15.701
and then Daniel, it's absolutely no,
that's not fair on you as a stakeholder.

394
00:24:15.701 --> 00:24:18.621
So what we need to do is
put our hands together, or

395
00:24:18.621 --> 00:24:23.329
somebody a program manager needs to talk
to us all about our requirements, and

396
00:24:23.329 --> 00:24:26.893
then they need to come up with
a solution that engages you for

397
00:24:26.893 --> 00:24:30.102
a certain amount of time,
but doesn't engage you for

398
00:24:30.102 --> 00:24:32.680
that entire six hours.
>> Right.

399
00:24:32.680 --> 00:24:34.180
>> And so, this is what program

400
00:24:34.180 --> 00:24:38.460
management is doing, program management
are planning that transition, and

401
00:24:38.460 --> 00:24:42.810
they are actually doing
the stakeholder engagement as it were.

402
00:24:44.260 --> 00:24:47.350
The other thing that we want to do is make
sure that once we've got the stakeholder's

403
00:24:47.350 --> 00:24:52.100
engaged, that we're able to sort of
mobilize those stakeholders as well.

404
00:24:52.100 --> 00:24:55.980
In other words, well, we've got to
keep on top of them, cuz that's

405
00:24:55.980 --> 00:24:59.660
something else that the program manager's
got to make sure is that, not only

406
00:24:59.660 --> 00:25:04.590
are they not using up six hours of your
time, but the hour that I use in review

407
00:25:04.590 --> 00:25:06.960
time is an hour that's spent wisely.
>> Right.

408
00:25:08.420 --> 00:25:11.350
>> I as a program manager do not want you

409
00:25:11.350 --> 00:25:17.260
to be spending an hour sitting twiddling
your thumbs, because Cherokee didn't have

410
00:25:17.260 --> 00:25:23.160
her information ready for you to get
working when you were available to her.

411
00:25:23.160 --> 00:25:25.110
And maybe if that was the case,

412
00:25:25.110 --> 00:25:29.280
then maybe you could spend that
hour this week with Daniel instead.

413
00:25:29.280 --> 00:25:31.770
So, as program manager,

414
00:25:31.770 --> 00:25:37.380
even though we may think that
a program manager is a senior role.

415
00:25:37.380 --> 00:25:41.810
And we think that the program
management role is a role that is, or

416
00:25:41.810 --> 00:25:45.350
shouldn’t be involved in
that sort of minutiae.

417
00:25:45.350 --> 00:25:49.110
Program manager is a coordination roll.

418
00:25:49.110 --> 00:25:51.850
And therefore, they need to ensure that

419
00:25:51.850 --> 00:25:56.540
we have the right level of coordination
across all of the projects.

420
00:25:56.540 --> 00:26:00.530
Ultimately what we want to do is
to deliver the project outputs.

421
00:26:00.530 --> 00:26:04.970
And we want to make sure that every single
project delivers the right outputs.

422
00:26:04.970 --> 00:26:09.750
But again, we're in program management
level, so we wanna make sure that every

423
00:26:09.750 --> 00:26:15.190
single project delivers the outputs
in a controlled manner.

424
00:26:15.190 --> 00:26:19.940
I don't want five different changes
all happening all at the same time.

425
00:26:19.940 --> 00:26:23.810
I can't cope with that,
I'm just a humble user, I don't need that.

426
00:26:23.810 --> 00:26:26.750
What I want is maybe one this week,
and then one next week, and

427
00:26:26.750 --> 00:26:27.820
then one the week after.

428
00:26:27.820 --> 00:26:30.240
Or maybe one this month, and
one the following month, and

429
00:26:30.240 --> 00:26:32.210
one the month after that.

430
00:26:32.210 --> 00:26:37.630
So that as a user,
then my releases are planned so

431
00:26:37.630 --> 00:26:39.350
that they're less disruptive to me.

432
00:26:39.350 --> 00:26:41.770
Remember what we said
in previous episodes.

433
00:26:41.770 --> 00:26:46.060
It's about maximum positive
impact on a project, and

434
00:26:46.060 --> 00:26:49.250
minimum negative impact
from implementing a change.

435
00:26:50.590 --> 00:26:56.295
So now, we've looked at program
management up to the point of actually

436
00:26:56.295 --> 00:26:58.935
delivering the individual project.

437
00:26:58.935 --> 00:27:03.965
And when we come back in our next episode,
we're gonna take that one stage further,

438
00:27:03.965 --> 00:27:08.076
and we're actually going to look at
transitioning those outputs, and

439
00:27:08.076 --> 00:27:11.065
transitioning the project as a whole,
the whole program,

440
00:27:11.065 --> 00:27:15.501
into the live environment.
>> All right Jo, thank you for helping us

441
00:27:15.501 --> 00:27:19.802
once again to focus in on what that
program manager needs to really be doing,

442
00:27:19.802 --> 00:27:22.289
as they start leading the idea of change,
or

443
00:27:22.289 --> 00:27:26.761
implementing the strategic change that's
been planned out for what we need.

444
00:27:26.761 --> 00:27:30.466
It really does help, because a lot of
times it's easy to get into the weeds and

445
00:27:30.466 --> 00:27:32.290
think that you have to do everything.

446
00:27:32.290 --> 00:27:36.118
But here Jo is showing us that there's
an importance, there is an order,

447
00:27:36.118 --> 00:27:39.328
there's an urgency to some of
the things that need to be done,

448
00:27:39.328 --> 00:27:41.768
and the program manager
has to help us to do so.

449
00:27:41.768 --> 00:27:44.198
But there is more to come, so
you want to Stay tuned for

450
00:27:44.198 --> 00:27:47.750
more organizational change management,
but that is for another day.

451
00:27:47.750 --> 00:27:51.521
So signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

452
00:27:51.521 --> 00:27:52.582
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

453
00:27:52.582 --> 00:27:54.264
>> Stay tuned right here for

454
00:27:54.264 --> 00:27:57.396
more of the organizational
change episodes.

455
00:27:57.396 --> 00:28:03.562
[MUSIC]

456
00:28:03.562 --> 00:28:06.984
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

>> You're watching ITProTV.

00:00:12.814 --> 00:00:15.519

8
00:00:15.519 --> 00:00:18.425
You're watching

9

10

And today we're continuing on a part

00:00:25.000 --> 00:00:29.960
And here to help us of course is our

12
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:30.620

13
00:00:30.620 --> 00:00:31.540
Jo, welcome to the show.

14
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:33.210

>> Thank you for having me, Ronnie.

15
00:00:33.210 --> 00:00:34.320
I'm absolutely great.

16
00:00:34.320 --> 00:00:36.330
How are you?
>> I am doing well,

17
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:40.530
Jo, as we're continuing on in this series
and understanding more about the idea of

18
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:44.200
organizational change and
program management.

19
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:46.070
I'm about to say project management here.

20
00:00:46.070 --> 00:00:49.550
In program management and trying to see
actually where their place actually is in

21
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:50.990
everything, is very interesting.

22
00:00:50.990 --> 00:00:52.990
So Jo, where are we picking up here?
>> Right,

23
00:00:52.990 --> 00:00:56.710
so, in our last episode,
we looked at program management and

24
00:00:56.710 --> 00:01:02.540
we looked at how we would organize
the projects within a program.

25
00:01:02.540 --> 00:01:07.860
And so what we did was we followed
the program itself from its inception,

26
00:01:07.860 --> 00:01:10.480
from the prioritization of
the individual projects and

27
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:14.500
the coordination of the resources right
the way through to understand it,

28
00:01:14.500 --> 00:01:16.960
identifying who our stakeholders are.

29
00:01:16.960 --> 00:01:20.370
And then mobilizing, as it were,
those stakeholders and

30
00:01:20.370 --> 00:01:24.120
ensuring that we get the right level
of engagement in those stakeholders.

31
00:01:24.120 --> 00:01:27.700
And now what we're doing is in this
particular episode we're going to be

32
00:01:27.700 --> 00:01:31.340
looking at implementing
the individual projects and

33
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:36.480
ensuring that we have the right
engagement from the organization.

34
00:01:36.480 --> 00:01:40.580
So those stakeholders that
are concerned with the organization.

35
00:01:40.580 --> 00:01:43.540
Now I've got to say something, and

36
00:01:43.540 --> 00:01:47.990
I've gotta mention this right now
because obviously we're looking at

37
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:51.590
the organizational change
management of programs here.

38
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:55.590
And we're gonna use the word, both here
and in the subsequent episode when we talk

39
00:01:55.590 --> 00:01:58.190
about project management,
we're gonna use the word transition.

40
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:04.144
Transition's a word that's been commonly
associated with service management and

41
00:02:04.144 --> 00:02:07.780
it's about transitioning something
into the live environment.

42
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:10.190
And again,
we're gonna use it in that same context,

43
00:02:10.190 --> 00:02:13.950
as transitioning a change into the live
environment or into the business.

44
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:17.210
But I wanna bring something else in here,
and

45
00:02:17.210 --> 00:02:20.370
I kind of wanna put a disclaimer in here.

46
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:25.570
Because I've gotta say that I
have been into organizations

47
00:02:25.570 --> 00:02:31.290
where the word transition simply
means handing something over.

48
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:35.480
That's not what a transition is.

49
00:02:35.480 --> 00:02:38.256
We've all heard the term DevOps, and

50
00:02:38.256 --> 00:02:42.020
DevOps simply means
development operations.

51
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:43.737
That's where it came from, DevOps.

52
00:02:43.737 --> 00:02:48.810
But the DevOps concept, it's a mindset,
it's really what it is.

53
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:50.210
It's a mindset which, I mean,

54
00:02:50.210 --> 00:02:54.210
we have some great tools that have
come along to support DevOps, but it's

55
00:02:54.210 --> 00:02:59.080
a mindset where we look at the synergy
between development and operations.

56
00:02:59.080 --> 00:03:03.035
And where we actually look at that
transition between development and

57
00:03:03.035 --> 00:03:04.880
operations.

58
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:08.890
Let's just say that Ronnie
is my developer and

59
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:11.940
Ronnie is really,
really good at developing.

60
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:14.530
And I'm not gonna detract from his skills.

61
00:03:15.650 --> 00:03:20.200
And I'm a service desk manager, and
I'm really good at supporting and

62
00:03:20.200 --> 00:03:23.350
making sure that the service is supported.

63
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:26.527
And I'm not gonna belittle my skills or
my team either.

64
00:03:26.527 --> 00:03:32.169
But the fact of the matter is that
when Ronnie just comes to me and

65
00:03:32.169 --> 00:03:36.640
hands something over to me and
says, here you go,

66
00:03:36.640 --> 00:03:39.948
here's your new piece of software.

67
00:03:39.948 --> 00:03:40.830
I'm not happy.

68
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:47.010
I'm not happy, and I have a really, really
low perception of Ronnie because of it.

69
00:03:47.010 --> 00:03:49.560
And it's not his fault,
because he's done his job.

70
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:51.540
But nevertheless,

71
00:03:51.540 --> 00:03:55.680
it's my team that are left picking up
the pieces when something goes wrong.

72
00:03:56.860 --> 00:04:00.920
So when support uninvolved
in the development and

73
00:04:00.920 --> 00:04:07.560
in the transition of a service learn
Ronnie doesn't know what to develop

74
00:04:07.560 --> 00:04:12.050
because he doesn't know how the users
are using a particular service.

75
00:04:13.090 --> 00:04:17.358
Sure, what Ronnie's done as a developer
is that he has spoken with the users and

76
00:04:17.358 --> 00:04:19.462
he's gathered their requirements and

77
00:04:19.462 --> 00:04:22.726
he's developed something that
meets their requirements.

78
00:04:22.726 --> 00:04:29.269
But nevertheless, my team understand
exactly how the user uses something.

79
00:04:30.520 --> 00:04:34.300
My team know it doesn't matter what
instructions you give the user,

80
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:35.120
they're not gonna follow them.

81
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:37.100
They're gonna do it this way.

82
00:04:37.100 --> 00:04:38.480
Because that's how they've always worked.

83
00:04:39.990 --> 00:04:44.060
My team know that even though their user
tells you that they're gonna be working

84
00:04:44.060 --> 00:04:47.600
until 5 PM every single Friday that
they always go home at 3 o'clock.

85
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:52.220
My team know this, and Ronnie doesn't.

86
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:59.280
And so if Ronnie doesn't work with me,
then what's going to happen

87
00:04:59.280 --> 00:05:02.800
is that Ronnie's gonna build what
the user requirements state.

88
00:05:02.800 --> 00:05:07.440
He's gonna build what the user asks for
and he's gonna give it to me.

89
00:05:09.898 --> 00:05:11.890
But something's gonna go wrong, and

90
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:14.890
it's not necessarily gonna go wrong
with the way that he's developed it.

91
00:05:14.890 --> 00:05:18.960
It's just the simple fact that because
Ronnie doesn't know what the users really

92
00:05:18.960 --> 00:05:26.080
do, then the users are gonna use something
in a way that Ronnie didn't design it for.

93
00:05:26.080 --> 00:05:27.460
And guess who's picking up the pieces?

94
00:05:28.500 --> 00:05:29.000
That'd be me.

95
00:05:30.975 --> 00:05:32.381
But the other thing is,

96
00:05:32.381 --> 00:05:37.023
now what's happened is that because
the users are using it in a different way,

97
00:05:37.023 --> 00:05:41.735
we've had to put another request in to
Ronnie, because Ronnie's gonna have to

98
00:05:41.735 --> 00:05:46.440
make some tweaks to the program that
he's developed and to this service.

99
00:05:46.440 --> 00:05:49.040
Because it's not working quite
the way the users wanted.

100
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:50.470
And guess what,
the users were unhappy with it, too.

101
00:05:50.470 --> 00:05:56.040
And they're unhappy cuz it doesn't work
in a way that they want it to work.

102
00:05:56.040 --> 00:05:59.760
Even though it ticks all of the boxes and
that meets all of the criteria that they

103
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:02.800
gave Ronnie, it still doesn't
work in a way that they like it.

104
00:06:04.060 --> 00:06:08.350
So you see, if Ronnie and
I don't talk, we can tick a box,

105
00:06:08.350 --> 00:06:11.170
but we're not providing value.

106
00:06:12.950 --> 00:06:16.970
And more importantly, we've got a definite
breakdown in communication between the two

107
00:06:16.970 --> 00:06:21.450
of us, because quite frankly,
right now, I'm not his biggest fan.

108
00:06:22.670 --> 00:06:25.550
Because what he's given me and
my team is a huge headache.

109
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:30.230
And then all he gets back from
me is criticism and complaints.

110
00:06:30.230 --> 00:06:32.072
And he's not my biggest fan either.

111
00:06:32.072 --> 00:06:35.310
And so it doesn't help our relationship.

112
00:06:36.950 --> 00:06:41.600
So when you use the word transition
in a project, I want you to be very,

113
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:44.380
very careful of that word.

114
00:06:44.380 --> 00:06:47.630
Because transition does not mean handover.

115
00:06:48.650 --> 00:06:52.390
Transition means simply that.

116
00:06:52.390 --> 00:06:56.080
It's a change of state,
a gradual change of state.

117
00:06:56.080 --> 00:07:00.750
It's a gradual move from
a development environment

118
00:07:00.750 --> 00:07:05.340
to an operational environment,
in this instance.

119
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:07.093
So what we're doing here,

120
00:07:07.093 --> 00:07:11.069
is we are transitioning a project
into the live environment.

121
00:07:11.069 --> 00:07:15.341
We are not handing it over, or
even throwing it over the wall,

122
00:07:15.341 --> 00:07:18.090
as I've seen in some instances [LAUGH].

123
00:07:18.090 --> 00:07:21.500
So be very careful when you
use that word transition and

124
00:07:21.500 --> 00:07:26.490
ensure that you are referring
to the synergy that exists

125
00:07:26.490 --> 00:07:31.060
between the development team and
the support team on your project.

126
00:07:31.060 --> 00:07:34.860
And this the role of the program manager,
to ensure that we've got the right level

127
00:07:34.860 --> 00:07:38.550
of stakeholder involvement
on your project.

128
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:41.440
You should have support people.

129
00:07:41.440 --> 00:07:45.880
Also on the project, they're to ensure
that the support aspect is covered and

130
00:07:45.880 --> 00:07:49.176
they're to ensure that the user
aspect is covered, too,

131
00:07:49.176 --> 00:07:52.154
because it doesn't matter
what the users tell you.

132
00:07:52.154 --> 00:07:57.837
It doesn't matter what they say they're
going to do, cuz nobody knows that, right?

133
00:07:57.837 --> 00:07:58.449
My team.

134
00:07:59.620 --> 00:08:03.900
So the program manager
is responsible then for

135
00:08:03.900 --> 00:08:08.960
making sure that we've got the right
level of commitment and involvement

136
00:08:08.960 --> 00:08:13.280
from all of the stakeholders, including
all of the support teams, as well.

137
00:08:14.620 --> 00:08:18.370
And so what the program manager
should be doing is also then

138
00:08:18.370 --> 00:08:21.200
at the transition of the project.

139
00:08:21.200 --> 00:08:25.500
They should be measuring
the adoption of the project.

140
00:08:25.500 --> 00:08:30.190
And the adoption of that new service and
the usage of the outcomes,

141
00:08:30.190 --> 00:08:32.340
as well and the usage of the output.

142
00:08:32.340 --> 00:08:35.605
Is a project actually being used?

143
00:08:35.605 --> 00:08:38.660
You see that's something else
that I want to mention and

144
00:08:38.660 --> 00:08:43.780
we just got a slide there just to show
you sorta short, medium and long term.

145
00:08:43.780 --> 00:08:47.370
But something else that I wanna
mention is that sometimes

146
00:08:48.380 --> 00:08:51.630
we get things wrong in project management,
believe it or not, and

147
00:08:51.630 --> 00:08:56.000
sometimes we might release something maybe
too late and it doesn't get used at all.

148
00:08:56.000 --> 00:08:59.493
Or sometimes we release something and
it's not too late,

149
00:08:59.493 --> 00:09:04.213
it's just that the users changed their
mind and so they don't end up using it.

150
00:09:04.213 --> 00:09:07.867
Or sometimes, because we didn't have
the synergy between Development and

151
00:09:07.867 --> 00:09:10.777
Operations, then something is
released that the users just

152
00:09:10.777 --> 00:09:14.100
simply don't wanna use anyway,
because they don't work that way.

153
00:09:15.760 --> 00:09:20.850
So what we want to do is, when a project
has been released, when it's part of

154
00:09:20.850 --> 00:09:24.910
a program, we wanna make sure that we're
measuring the results of that project.

155
00:09:24.910 --> 00:09:26.822
So we're measuring short-term results.

156
00:09:26.822 --> 00:09:32.450
Which is the assessment of whether
that project has been released,

157
00:09:32.450 --> 00:09:34.030
is it being used?

158
00:09:34.030 --> 00:09:38.770
And then in the medium term we want to
sorta measure whether the application

159
00:09:38.770 --> 00:09:43.020
is working, as in the application of
the project not the application as in IT

160
00:09:43.020 --> 00:09:45.110
terms of the application.

161
00:09:45.110 --> 00:09:48.635
In other words, is it working well?

162
00:09:48.635 --> 00:09:50.370
Is it working without errors?

163
00:09:51.370 --> 00:09:54.570
Are they able to use it as long as they've
got the relevant amount of training?

164
00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:59.150
And then in the long term we want to
make sure that a realization is there

165
00:09:59.150 --> 00:10:00.640
on the benefits.

166
00:10:00.640 --> 00:10:05.030
In other words, we've got a return on the
investment, or value on investment return.

167
00:10:07.130 --> 00:10:12.310
So we want to implement in an agile way,
but

168
00:10:12.310 --> 00:10:18.360
we also want to ensure that we can measure
the success of our project, as well.

169
00:10:18.360 --> 00:10:22.260
So the program management
is able to say yes or

170
00:10:22.260 --> 00:10:24.750
no whether a success has been achieved.

171
00:10:27.060 --> 00:10:32.740
And then we also want to ensure the
program management on an ongoing basis is

172
00:10:32.740 --> 00:10:38.480
managing the projects themselves
throughout the transition.

173
00:10:38.480 --> 00:10:42.000
And we've got here, I love the words that
it says at the top of these boxes here,

174
00:10:42.000 --> 00:10:43.512
which is think success.

175
00:10:43.512 --> 00:10:48.299
We wanna have a positive approach to
managing all of the synergy between

176
00:10:48.299 --> 00:10:51.900
our project and
to managing all of our stakeholders.

177
00:10:51.900 --> 00:10:55.790
So we talked about communicating
actively and contributing dynamically.

178
00:10:55.790 --> 00:10:59.964
The last thing that anybody wants
whether it's a project manager or

179
00:10:59.964 --> 00:11:05.089
whether it's any sorta stakeholder is
somebody that's going to be dictatorial,

180
00:11:05.089 --> 00:11:09.698
is somebody that is going to be sorta,
they say authoritatively but, no,

181
00:11:09.698 --> 00:11:13.091
we don't want somebody
who's gonna be dictatorial.

182
00:11:13.091 --> 00:11:16.687
And we don't want somebody who's gonna
be sorta passive aggressive about

183
00:11:16.687 --> 00:11:18.010
communication, as well.

184
00:11:19.390 --> 00:11:21.850
I mean, I'm gonna hold my hands up here.

185
00:11:21.850 --> 00:11:26.598
I will admit now that I am British and
sarcasm is in our genes.

186
00:11:26.598 --> 00:11:30.460
And I [LAUGH] can be one of the most
sarcastic people in this world.

187
00:11:30.460 --> 00:11:35.490
And in fact I was having a discussion
with Bonne about this just the other day.

188
00:11:35.490 --> 00:11:40.140
About the fact that us British and
we were rude bunch where we want to be.

189
00:11:40.140 --> 00:11:41.150
But it's not that were rude,

190
00:11:41.150 --> 00:11:44.600
it's just that sometimes we can
come across as a little bit blunt.

191
00:11:44.600 --> 00:11:46.190
But okay, I'll say what I think.

192
00:11:47.330 --> 00:11:50.128
But at least we can't be accused
of being passive aggressive.

193
00:11:50.128 --> 00:11:53.345
[LAUGH] We're just aggressive sometimes.
>> [LAUGH]

194
00:11:53.345 --> 00:11:55.779
>> But you wanna communicate actively,

195
00:11:55.779 --> 00:11:59.090
we don't want that passive aggressiveness.

196
00:11:59.090 --> 00:12:04.980
The last thing that you need, as a Program
Manager, is a group of individual projects

197
00:12:04.980 --> 00:12:09.350
where they're all working in silos, and
they're not working as part of a team.

198
00:12:09.350 --> 00:12:15.535
They're not collaborating with each other,
they're because of your bad management,

199
00:12:15.535 --> 00:12:21.275
because you have fostered a culture where
you fostered competitiveness across

200
00:12:21.275 --> 00:12:26.175
your projects, or because you
fostered some sort of rivalry there.

201
00:12:26.175 --> 00:12:29.025
Or because simply you just don't get
on with anybody within the project.

202
00:12:30.065 --> 00:12:34.645
So we wanna make sure in order for
a project to be successful, that across

203
00:12:34.645 --> 00:12:40.310
the entire program that
we are communicating and

204
00:12:40.310 --> 00:12:45.990
managing in a way that nurtures
rather than is dictatorial.

205
00:12:47.030 --> 00:12:51.170
But we still want to
make sure that we manage.

206
00:12:51.170 --> 00:12:53.110
That doesn't mean that we just sit back,
put our feet up and

207
00:12:53.110 --> 00:12:54.320
let them go on with it.

208
00:12:54.320 --> 00:12:58.670
We still gotta manage because we've gotta
coordinate across all of our projects.

209
00:13:00.650 --> 00:13:05.090
So the next thing that I wanna come across
here is once we have implemented our

210
00:13:05.090 --> 00:13:11.820
project, we wanna make sense of,
[LAUGH] well, the entire program.

211
00:13:11.820 --> 00:13:17.030
And make sense of the entire program
in respect to the actual organization.

212
00:13:19.370 --> 00:13:22.430
Am I making sense to my team?

213
00:13:22.430 --> 00:13:26.040
Am I making sense to my organization?

214
00:13:26.040 --> 00:13:29.351
Does the project,
does the program make sense?

215
00:13:29.351 --> 00:13:33.460
We call this sense making.

216
00:13:33.460 --> 00:13:34.510
And sense making,

217
00:13:34.510 --> 00:13:39.830
we've got a quick slide there that's just
giving you a brief description of this.

218
00:13:39.830 --> 00:13:43.910
By sense making it refers to the practices

219
00:13:43.910 --> 00:13:48.070
enabling individuals making sense of
what's happening around them, and

220
00:13:48.070 --> 00:13:52.990
that came out of the PMP book.

221
00:13:52.990 --> 00:13:58.660
Which is really about ensuring
both the organization

222
00:13:58.660 --> 00:14:01.740
and the organization that
are receiving the change, and

223
00:14:01.740 --> 00:14:06.280
also those that
are delivering any change and

224
00:14:06.280 --> 00:14:10.710
delivering any project are able to
justify why they're doing something.

225
00:14:12.220 --> 00:14:16.710
And something that I've always applied
to any team that I've worked with,

226
00:14:16.710 --> 00:14:20.840
if you can't justify why you're doing
something and I've mentioned this

227
00:14:20.840 --> 00:14:25.370
in a few previous episodes as well,
it's asking the question why.

228
00:14:25.370 --> 00:14:27.110
If you can't justify why,

229
00:14:27.110 --> 00:14:32.190
then there's not going to be the
motivation there to actually fulfill their

230
00:14:32.190 --> 00:14:37.960
part of the activities and
what their responsibilities are.

231
00:14:37.960 --> 00:14:42.810
If I'm asking you to do something and
I'm not justifying why I'm asking

232
00:14:42.810 --> 00:14:46.500
you to do it,
then you're probably not going to do it.

233
00:14:48.020 --> 00:14:52.505
If I say to you, I'd like you to go and
fill that cup up with water, and I don't

234
00:14:52.505 --> 00:14:56.205
to explain that actually I'd like you to
go to fill that cup up with water because

235
00:14:56.205 --> 00:15:00.085
there's a plant over there and it needs
water and it hasn't been watered for days.

236
00:15:00.085 --> 00:15:03.825
Then you might not go and fill that cup
up with water or you might leave it for

237
00:15:03.825 --> 00:15:07.285
a few hours when actually that thing looks
like it's on its last legs right now.

238
00:15:09.625 --> 00:15:13.455
So we want to encourage the question why.

239
00:15:14.990 --> 00:15:18.820
But the same time, I want you to be
prepared for the question why, and

240
00:15:18.820 --> 00:15:23.940
any good program manager should be
able to justify why we undertake any

241
00:15:23.940 --> 00:15:29.490
specific activity in any project,
and in any program.

242
00:15:30.670 --> 00:15:33.560
Why are you using Ronnie for
this particular task?

243
00:15:33.560 --> 00:15:36.510
Well, I'm using Ronnie for
this task because Ronnie is

244
00:15:36.510 --> 00:15:40.538
available at 7:30 on a morning and
because Ronnie has skills X, Y and Z.

245
00:15:40.538 --> 00:15:43.490
And that's what I'm using Ronnie for
this task.

246
00:15:45.270 --> 00:15:50.868
And so when you approach Ronnie, cuz I
like to use Ronnie cuz he never says no.

247
00:15:50.868 --> 00:15:53.732
But when I approach Ronnie,
I can say to him, Ronnie,

248
00:15:53.732 --> 00:15:57.979
I know you're in at 7:30 in the morning
and I know that you have these skills.

249
00:15:57.979 --> 00:16:00.795
So would you be able to do this for me?

250
00:16:00.795 --> 00:16:03.527
Yes.
>> See, I told you, he always says yes.

251
00:16:03.527 --> 00:16:05.684
He never says no to me.

252
00:16:05.684 --> 00:16:10.448
But that's why I'm going to do that,
because I want his commitment,

253
00:16:10.448 --> 00:16:12.730
because I want his involvement.

254
00:16:12.730 --> 00:16:14.390
So, I'm going to justify why.

255
00:16:14.390 --> 00:16:18.640
If I just simply turned around to him and
say, can you do this tomorrow morning?

256
00:16:18.640 --> 00:16:22.330
He doesn't understand the priority,
he doesn't understand why I'm asking him,

257
00:16:22.330 --> 00:16:25.450
and he might just push
it to the back burner.

258
00:16:25.450 --> 00:16:31.900
So think about how your forming that
justification as a program manager.

259
00:16:31.900 --> 00:16:36.440
What you want to do is to have a committed
team that is going to help you to

260
00:16:36.440 --> 00:16:41.390
implement your projects and to deliver
the outcomes that the customers want.

261
00:16:41.390 --> 00:16:44.970
In a way then they can embed that change.

262
00:16:44.970 --> 00:16:46.980
I mean that's what it say here.

263
00:16:46.980 --> 00:16:52.390
We talk about in the green at the top you
see we've broken down that lifecycle.

264
00:16:52.390 --> 00:16:57.330
And in that green at the top it says,
conduct sense making activities.

265
00:16:57.330 --> 00:17:01.869
What we're trying to do is ensure that
that we understand our environment.

266
00:17:01.869 --> 00:17:05.414
Because you know understanding
your environment right now, and

267
00:17:05.414 --> 00:17:09.280
understanding why a project is a success
and what makes a project fail,

268
00:17:09.280 --> 00:17:11.140
and why it isn't a success.

269
00:17:11.140 --> 00:17:14.260
That will help you in your next program.

270
00:17:15.600 --> 00:17:19.410
So we have to ensure that after
we've delivered a project,

271
00:17:19.410 --> 00:17:22.190
that we make sense of our environment.

272
00:17:22.190 --> 00:17:26.618
But we have to ensure that before
we even start on a project,

273
00:17:26.618 --> 00:17:30.527
that we are justifying why
we're doing something.

274
00:17:30.527 --> 00:17:33.256
Because if we don't, then quite frankly,

275
00:17:33.256 --> 00:17:37.110
we're not going to get the commitment
from our project team.

276
00:17:38.360 --> 00:17:42.505
And then of course, I've already
talked about benefits realization.

277
00:17:42.505 --> 00:17:45.995
And benefit realization is, well,

278
00:17:45.995 --> 00:17:50.395
we've talked about short term benefits and
medium term and long term benefits.

279
00:17:50.395 --> 00:17:54.985
Benefit realization is when we say that
this project has been completed and

280
00:17:54.985 --> 00:17:59.295
we have measured the benefits
that have been achieved.

281
00:18:01.060 --> 00:18:05.993
This is not a one-off activity.

282
00:18:05.993 --> 00:18:11.105
You don't just measure your benefits as
soon as you implemented the project and

283
00:18:11.105 --> 00:18:15.820
then walk away and say, well that's it,
job done we did that one.

284
00:18:15.820 --> 00:18:21.806
No you don't, okay I expect benefits
realization to be done at implementation.

285
00:18:21.806 --> 00:18:26.030
And then I expect it to be done three
months later and then six months later and

286
00:18:26.030 --> 00:18:29.090
even a year after project
has been implemented.

287
00:18:29.090 --> 00:18:33.410
Because for a start you cannot
measure a benefit immediately.

288
00:18:33.410 --> 00:18:37.065
Because if we remember that
emotional cycle of change, or

289
00:18:37.065 --> 00:18:42.225
even we remember the Gartner Hype Cycle,
with the peak of inflated expectation.

290
00:18:42.225 --> 00:18:47.239
At the time of deployment
the initial impact on the live

291
00:18:47.239 --> 00:18:52.533
environment is always?
>> On the live environment?

292
00:18:52.533 --> 00:18:53.945
>> A blank face.

293
00:18:53.945 --> 00:18:55.680
[LAUGH] It's always negative.
>> Yeah.

294
00:18:56.850 --> 00:18:57.810
>> Because it's an impact.

295
00:18:59.290 --> 00:19:00.890
And it's always a negative impact.

296
00:19:00.890 --> 00:19:02.290
When something happens,

297
00:19:02.290 --> 00:19:06.430
even if you're just getting a new toy,
like I got my new watch that time.

298
00:19:06.430 --> 00:19:09.955
Even if you're just getting a new toy it's
going to have a negative impact on your

299
00:19:09.955 --> 00:19:11.140
environment, because you know what?

300
00:19:11.140 --> 00:19:11.970
You're going to spend

301
00:19:11.970 --> 00:19:13.540
five hours playing with it.
>> [LAUGH]

302
00:19:13.540 --> 00:19:15.170
>> You're not actually gonna get

303
00:19:15.170 --> 00:19:16.730
any benefit out of it.

304
00:19:16.730 --> 00:19:19.590
So that's not when you
measure your benefits.

305
00:19:19.590 --> 00:19:24.033
You measure for benefits realization
after implementation, sure,

306
00:19:24.033 --> 00:19:27.880
but then you've gotta make sure that your
benefits are gonna improve over time.

307
00:19:29.120 --> 00:19:32.370
And so you measure your benefits
after you've implemented.

308
00:19:32.370 --> 00:19:36.961
And then at periodic times,
to ensure that not only do you achieve

309
00:19:36.961 --> 00:19:42.070
the optimum benefits, but
that also those benefits are embedded.

310
00:19:42.070 --> 00:19:44.030
And that the project is embedded.

311
00:19:44.030 --> 00:19:48.390
And you don't go back to doing
what you were doing before.

312
00:19:48.390 --> 00:19:51.880
Because that's something else
that happens within any project.

313
00:19:51.880 --> 00:19:57.350
Is that people can go back to
doing what they had before if

314
00:19:57.350 --> 00:20:01.960
we're not able to embed that change,
we're not able to make it successful.

315
00:20:03.600 --> 00:20:08.080
So what we've done in these last two
episodes, then, is we've looked at

316
00:20:08.080 --> 00:20:12.730
organizational change management
from a program management level.

317
00:20:12.730 --> 00:20:14.370
And in our next episode,

318
00:20:14.370 --> 00:20:19.320
which we'd like you to join us in, we're
going to be looking at implementation of

319
00:20:19.320 --> 00:20:23.250
change at a individual project level.
>> All right Jo.

320
00:20:23.250 --> 00:20:27.110
Thank you once again for helping us to
round out our bit of knowledge here on

321
00:20:27.110 --> 00:20:29.060
program change management.

322
00:20:29.060 --> 00:20:30.870
There is a lot to cover and

323
00:20:30.870 --> 00:20:35.960
sometimes we do forget some of those
issues that're easily forgotten.

324
00:20:35.960 --> 00:20:38.300
Because we haven't spend
anytime in doing it.

325
00:20:38.300 --> 00:20:42.220
But here Jo is actually introduced us
to a little bit more of the concept and

326
00:20:42.220 --> 00:20:43.380
dived a little bit deeper.

327
00:20:43.380 --> 00:20:46.870
But there is more to come, so
stay tuned for that as well.

328
00:20:46.870 --> 00:20:50.650
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

329
00:20:50.650 --> 00:20:51.540
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

330
00:20:51.540 --> 00:20:52.569
>> Stay tuned right here for

331
00:20:52.569 --> 00:20:54.588
more organizational
change management shows.

332
00:20:54.588 --> 00:21:02.343
[MUSIC]

333
00:21:02.343 --> 00:21:04.821
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

project management level,
we've looked at change for

program management level and we've looked

And when we come back in our next episode,

>> All right Jo, well thank you for

00:14:21.422 --> 00:14:22.150
the next-
>> [LAUGH]

00:14:22.150 --> 00:14:23.141
>> Episode as well,

but now remember that in this episode,

6

change management show.

7

I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

13

And now you are saying that

we're gonna get ready to do

18

Now I know that in previous episodes,

we have looked at organizational
change management.

20

The big transformational change from

23
