We've looked at how we would formulate
change at every single level

24
00:01:13.927 --> 00:01:17.977
within portfolio management and
program management, and

25
00:01:17.977 --> 00:01:20.491
also in project management as well.

26
00:01:20.491 --> 00:01:25.946
But one of the things that I've said in
every single episode, really, is the fact

27
00:01:25.946 --> 00:01:31.417
that you cannot, and we can't, dictate
exactly how you'll change processes.

28
00:01:31.417 --> 00:01:34.297
In other words,
how that project should look,

29
00:01:34.297 --> 00:01:39.050
how you actually plan your change, and
how you actually perform your change.

30
00:01:39.050 --> 00:01:40.640
And we can't, we still can't.

31
00:01:40.640 --> 00:01:44.165
However, there are certain
things that we have to do for

32
00:01:44.165 --> 00:01:46.646
every single organizational change.

33
00:01:46.646 --> 00:01:49.325
I'm bearing in mind that,
in organizational change,

34
00:01:49.325 --> 00:01:51.320
we've got to bring in the people as well.

35
00:01:51.320 --> 00:01:53.312
We have to factor in the people.

36
00:01:53.312 --> 00:01:55.162
Because as I always say, and

37
00:01:55.162 --> 00:01:58.270
I'll say it again just because I like to.
>> [LAUGH]

38
00:01:58.270 --> 00:01:59.827
>> But all we need is one negative

39
00:01:59.827 --> 00:02:04.125
person and that's going to undermine
the effects of 500 positive people, and

40
00:02:04.125 --> 00:02:06.930
that's exactly what we don't want to do.

41
00:02:06.930 --> 00:02:11.150
So we have to remember our people and we
have to perform the relevant stakeholder

42
00:02:11.150 --> 00:02:15.230
management, as we've discussed
in a lot of previous episodes.

43
00:02:15.230 --> 00:02:18.553
So what we're actually going to do
now then, is we're actually going to,

44
00:02:18.553 --> 00:02:21.794
well we're gonna plan the change,
we're gonna implement the change.

45
00:02:21.794 --> 00:02:27.386
So we're gonna start off by
formulating the change at any level.

46
00:02:27.386 --> 00:02:31.758
Whether it's at portfolio level, whether
it's at program level, or whether it's

47
00:02:31.758 --> 00:02:35.720
at project level, we're first of all
going to have to formulate the change.

48
00:02:35.720 --> 00:02:39.262
And if you remember, and I'm actually
going to, I was looking at one particular

49
00:02:39.262 --> 00:02:42.940
slide, but what I'm gonna do is I'm
just gonna is backtrack a little bit.

50
00:02:42.940 --> 00:02:48.517
But if you remember this particular slide,
and this one looked at project management

51
00:02:48.517 --> 00:02:53.330
specifically, but this is what we
call the Change Life Cycle Framework.

52
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:58.020
And if you remember,
it split up into, well, sections.

53
00:02:58.020 --> 00:03:01.329
So we have a section for formulating
the change, we have a section for

54
00:03:01.329 --> 00:03:02.420
planning the change.

55
00:03:02.420 --> 00:03:05.677
And we have a section for
implementing, and

56
00:03:05.677 --> 00:03:10.000
then managing the transition and
sustaining the change.

57
00:03:10.000 --> 00:03:12.128
That's embedding the change.

58
00:03:12.128 --> 00:03:13.380
So here we are then,

59
00:03:13.380 --> 00:03:18.250
in this particular episode we're actually
going to be looking at all of this.

60
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:21.933
We're gonna be looking at how we
actually implement the change.

61
00:03:21.933 --> 00:03:25.329
Let's take a look at some of
the practicalities of this.

62
00:03:25.329 --> 00:03:27.665
So the first thing that I'm gonna do is,

63
00:03:27.665 --> 00:03:31.804
I'm going to quickly jump with this
particular, yes, and it worked.

64
00:03:31.804 --> 00:03:37.165
So I'm just gonna take us through
these particular stages here,

65
00:03:37.165 --> 00:03:42.533
because in formulating the change
what do we actually have to do?

66
00:03:42.533 --> 00:03:45.964
Whether we're at portfolio level,
whether we're at program level, or

67
00:03:45.964 --> 00:03:47.580
whether we're at project level.

68
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:51.520
We have got to,
well that first column there,

69
00:03:51.520 --> 00:03:55.574
identify any other
resources that we may need.

70
00:03:55.574 --> 00:04:02.948
This is any other activities that fall
outside of the boundaries of the project.

71
00:04:02.948 --> 00:04:07.150
So let's think about something that
maybe a supplier may bring in to us.

72
00:04:07.150 --> 00:04:13.293
Something that an external vendor,
an external supply may bring to us.

73
00:04:13.293 --> 00:04:18.488
Something that a customer may
bring to the change as well.

74
00:04:18.488 --> 00:04:20.520
So at this particular point,

75
00:04:20.520 --> 00:04:25.250
what we want to do is identify who
any of these additional people are.

76
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:29.030
We know who we've got in our project and
we know who we've got in our program.

77
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:31.300
We know who we've got
within our portfolio.

78
00:04:31.300 --> 00:04:36.730
And don't forget both portfolio management
and program management are responsible for

79
00:04:36.730 --> 00:04:39.900
ensuring that we've got
the right resources.

80
00:04:39.900 --> 00:04:44.110
So here we have to identify where
the overlaps of these resources are and

81
00:04:44.110 --> 00:04:46.370
where we need additional resources.

82
00:04:46.370 --> 00:04:50.511
And that means we've got to
identify the stakeholders,

83
00:04:50.511 --> 00:04:54.660
as well as identify in
the expectations for each change.

84
00:04:54.660 --> 00:04:56.250
This is on that second column.

85
00:04:57.470 --> 00:05:02.151
What does every single stakeholder
want out of each change?

86
00:05:02.151 --> 00:05:04.583
What am I expecting to see?

87
00:05:06.125 --> 00:05:10.379
Sometimes we write things down and
we like to publicize things,

88
00:05:10.379 --> 00:05:13.059
maybe service exceptions, criteria,

89
00:05:13.059 --> 00:05:17.970
the sort of the things that we're going
to deliver as part of the project.

90
00:05:17.970 --> 00:05:22.540
And sometimes different people have
different understandings as to what's been

91
00:05:22.540 --> 00:05:23.220
written down.

92
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:30.240
Now if I were to read certain things, I'd
probably have one interpretation on it,

93
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:33.090
and Ronnie may well have
a different interpretation too.

94
00:05:34.120 --> 00:05:37.687
And that's unfortunately the way
that everything happens.

95
00:05:37.687 --> 00:05:41.590
Is that we all read something,
it's a bit like going to the movies.

96
00:05:41.590 --> 00:05:42.130
I don't know,

97
00:05:42.130 --> 00:05:46.830
we were talking in the office about
going to a movie just the other day.

98
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:50.160
And now people are reading the book,
because they've gone to see the movie and

99
00:05:50.160 --> 00:05:50.770
then they're saying,

100
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:53.940
well the book reads something
completely different to the movie.

101
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:59.205
And I always say, one of the reasons why
I'm here is because you can go away and

102
00:05:59.205 --> 00:06:01.879
read a book, nothing wrong with that.

103
00:06:01.879 --> 00:06:06.517
But why I'm here is to make sure that you
put the right interpretation on that book.

104
00:06:06.517 --> 00:06:10.114
Because you see, your interpretation
on what you've read is different from,

105
00:06:10.114 --> 00:06:12.539
say Ronnie's interpretation
on what you've read.

106
00:06:12.539 --> 00:06:15.772
Which happens to also be different
on the movie producer and

107
00:06:15.772 --> 00:06:19.576
director's interpretation on
what they've read as well.

108
00:06:19.576 --> 00:06:24.230
What my role is, is to make sure that
you actually have the interpretation

109
00:06:24.230 --> 00:06:27.992
of whatever has been
written down of the author.

110
00:06:27.992 --> 00:06:33.140
You are the author's interpretation,
and so that why we have training,

111
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:38.800
because training ensures that we will have
that consistency in our interpretation.

112
00:06:38.800 --> 00:06:43.760
And so when it comes to our expectation
setting we've got to make sure that,

113
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:49.150
with any change, whether it is
a portfolio or program or project level.

114
00:06:49.150 --> 00:06:53.687
That the person that's responsible for
that project or for

115
00:06:53.687 --> 00:06:58.870
the portfolio or for the program,
is able to manage expectations.

116
00:06:58.870 --> 00:07:03.011
I think you made a comment actually
a little while ago, Ronnie.

117
00:07:03.011 --> 00:07:05.964
And it might have been
in a previous episode or

118
00:07:05.964 --> 00:07:11.740
it might have been outside of an episode,
something about under or over-delivering?

119
00:07:11.740 --> 00:07:16.650
Setting expectations at a certain level
and then making sure that we over-deliver

120
00:07:16.650 --> 00:07:18.891
on those expectations.
>> Right.

121
00:07:18.891 --> 00:07:21.867
The one thing that you don't want to
do is over set the expectations and

122
00:07:21.867 --> 00:07:23.399
then under-deliver.
>> Correct.

123
00:07:23.399 --> 00:07:26.261
>> Because you lose all your integrity as

124
00:07:26.261 --> 00:07:30.733
a service provider, and
as a supplier of an IT service, and

125
00:07:30.733 --> 00:07:34.670
as a supplier of a product
within a project.

126
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:39.159
You don't wanna miss-set expectations,
so that's why its very important,

127
00:07:39.159 --> 00:07:41.839
it's key when we're
formulating the change,

128
00:07:41.839 --> 00:07:45.397
to ensure that we understand who
every single stakeholder is.

129
00:07:45.397 --> 00:07:51.077
And remember from a previous episode,
a stakeholder is an interested party.

130
00:07:51.077 --> 00:07:54.463
So we understand who those
stakeholders are and

131
00:07:54.463 --> 00:07:57.771
then we set their
expectations accordingly.

132
00:07:57.771 --> 00:08:02.750
Being very, very careful that we don't
want to overpromise and underdeliver.

133
00:08:02.750 --> 00:08:05.050
We want to underpromise and
then overdeliver.

134
00:08:06.670 --> 00:08:11.030
And then what we also have to do is
ensure that we coordinate all of

135
00:08:11.030 --> 00:08:14.250
the activities that all of these
stakeholders are performing.

136
00:08:15.740 --> 00:08:18.360
So the stakeholders,
some of them may just be.

137
00:08:18.360 --> 00:08:22.100
Remember, I talked about a RACI matrix,
as well, in a previous episode.

138
00:08:22.100 --> 00:08:25.930
Some of the stakeholders
may just be informed.

139
00:08:25.930 --> 00:08:28.080
And, therefore, their activities are,

140
00:08:28.080 --> 00:08:31.000
well, actually I'm gonna
ask this question.

141
00:08:31.000 --> 00:08:35.120
So if a stakeholder was just informed or
something, if I'm just telling you about

142
00:08:35.120 --> 00:08:39.806
something, do you have a responsibility?
>> I don't know if I have a real

143
00:08:39.806 --> 00:08:46.382
responsibility in the change itself as
much as just to be able to acknowledge

144
00:08:46.382 --> 00:08:52.430
that I've received the information.
>> Should I tell him?

145
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:55.694
That's wrong.
>> Well there you go.

146
00:08:55.694 --> 00:08:57.977
>> [LAUGH] Communication is a two-way

147
00:08:57.977 --> 00:08:58.850
process.

148
00:08:58.850 --> 00:09:00.921
You have a responsibility
to tell me if you didn't

149
00:09:00.921 --> 00:09:02.489
understand something.
>> Okay.

150
00:09:02.489 --> 00:09:04.735
>> And you also have a responsibility

151
00:09:04.735 --> 00:09:09.540
to tell me if you want clarification,
if you'd like me to rephrase it, or

152
00:09:09.540 --> 00:09:12.725
if you didn't like what you've been told.

153
00:09:12.725 --> 00:09:16.425
So that's not necessarily just
about not understanding it,

154
00:09:16.425 --> 00:09:19.615
but it's whether you didn't
like what's being told.

155
00:09:19.615 --> 00:09:22.545
Remember what I said to you right at
the beginning of this episode is that

156
00:09:22.545 --> 00:09:26.447
one negative person can
undermine 500 positive people.

157
00:09:26.447 --> 00:09:27.725
>> All right, so, Jo, if

158
00:09:29.030 --> 00:09:33.610
I am not a part of the organization,
why does it matter if you inform me and

159
00:09:33.610 --> 00:09:35.270
I don't like it?
>> Because you talk to

160
00:09:35.270 --> 00:09:36.550
people.
>> Okay.

161
00:09:36.550 --> 00:09:38.280
>> And you'll talk to people within my

162
00:09:38.280 --> 00:09:41.260
organization, and
you might sow the seeds of doubt.

163
00:09:42.460 --> 00:09:46.690
More importantly, you might have a better
way of doing something that I didn't know

164
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:47.510
anything about.

165
00:09:48.580 --> 00:09:51.200
So you do have a responsibility
to feed that back,

166
00:09:51.200 --> 00:09:54.030
especially if it's going
to impact your life.

167
00:09:54.030 --> 00:09:57.700
Let's say you were a supplier and
I was purchasing something from you,

168
00:09:57.700 --> 00:10:03.710
as part of a project I was purchasing
a particular product from you.

169
00:10:03.710 --> 00:10:04.560
And I went to you and

170
00:10:04.560 --> 00:10:07.840
I said, okay, then this is the date
that I need the product by.

171
00:10:09.420 --> 00:10:13.460
You can either just sit there and say,
okay, then fine, I've been informed.

172
00:10:13.460 --> 00:10:16.360
Or you could come back to me and
say, well, do you know what?

173
00:10:16.360 --> 00:10:19.256
We've got a new release of
that product due a week later.

174
00:10:19.256 --> 00:10:23.877
So how about you hold off for a week and
we can get you the latest version?

175
00:10:25.955 --> 00:10:29.403
Easier for you to support because you
will be supporting it in the long

176
00:10:29.403 --> 00:10:30.165
run.
>> Right.

177
00:10:30.165 --> 00:10:32.589
>> Potentially easier for you to support,

178
00:10:32.589 --> 00:10:35.162
but you would have some influence in that.

179
00:10:35.162 --> 00:10:38.642
Now, you might turn round to me, you might
challenge me, and you might say to me,

180
00:10:38.642 --> 00:10:41.710
well, in that case then what
I'm doing is consulting Ronnie.

181
00:10:41.710 --> 00:10:42.803
No, I wasn't.

182
00:10:42.803 --> 00:10:45.148
I was telling him what
my requirements were.

183
00:10:45.148 --> 00:10:48.290
I wasn't asking for his opinion.

184
00:10:48.290 --> 00:10:50.250
I was telling him what
my requirements were.

185
00:10:50.250 --> 00:10:55.030
But ultimately he was gonna be impacted
in that particular scenario so

186
00:10:55.030 --> 00:10:56.580
I'm gonna tell you.

187
00:10:56.580 --> 00:11:00.650
And you have a responsibility to
tell me if there's something that

188
00:11:01.760 --> 00:11:05.220
you want included in my consideration.

189
00:11:05.220 --> 00:11:07.800
You have a responsibility
to give me your opinions.

190
00:11:09.100 --> 00:11:13.110
Your opinion might just be, and
which it is in a lot of cases, when

191
00:11:13.110 --> 00:11:16.740
you get something on email, let's face it,
and you just say, yeah, that's great.

192
00:11:16.740 --> 00:11:18.860
And then that's as much as you send back.

193
00:11:18.860 --> 00:11:20.950
That might be your involvement.

194
00:11:20.950 --> 00:11:23.986
But, nevertheless,
even if you're just informed,

195
00:11:23.986 --> 00:11:26.499
you have a responsibility
to feed that back.

196
00:11:28.334 --> 00:11:29.530
He doesn't look convinced.

197
00:11:29.530 --> 00:11:30.740
Either that or

198
00:11:30.740 --> 00:11:34.964
he doesn't look happy about it.
>> The idea here, again,

199
00:11:34.964 --> 00:11:39.375
I kind of think about this,
if they are just on the periphery and

200
00:11:39.375 --> 00:11:45.138
even though they are a stakeholder in
a sense, there's no real responsibility.

201
00:11:45.138 --> 00:11:49.456
If you change, I just have to deal with
it, except for the fact that I might be

202
00:11:49.456 --> 00:11:51.300
able to influence someone.
>> Right.

203
00:11:51.300 --> 00:11:52.370
>> But not necessarily

204
00:11:52.370 --> 00:11:53.760
I would influence someone.
>> But

205
00:11:53.760 --> 00:11:55.970
you might be able to influence something.
>> Right.

206
00:11:55.970 --> 00:11:56.840
>> And that's the thing,

207
00:11:56.840 --> 00:11:58.840
you will never know.

208
00:11:58.840 --> 00:12:02.910
If I don't give you the opportunity,
then you are going to be much more

209
00:12:02.910 --> 00:12:07.980
negative about any change than
if I gave you the opportunity.

210
00:12:07.980 --> 00:12:13.345
From a project management prospective, if
I give you the opportunity to be involved,

211
00:12:13.345 --> 00:12:17.695
then at least I'm identifying any
potential sources of resistance.

212
00:12:17.695 --> 00:12:19.227
And I've given you the opportunity.

213
00:12:19.227 --> 00:12:21.166
You haven't come back and
said anything else.

214
00:12:21.166 --> 00:12:24.282
So, therefore,
what I can do is I can say, well,

215
00:12:24.282 --> 00:12:27.910
at least I've given Ronnie
the opportunity to respond.

216
00:12:27.910 --> 00:12:29.335
He hasn't responded.

217
00:12:29.335 --> 00:12:33.811
Therefore, I've either got to,
depending on how well I know Ronnie,

218
00:12:33.811 --> 00:12:37.623
I've either got to eliminate
him as a source of resistance.

219
00:12:37.623 --> 00:12:41.876
Or actually I should be incredibly
worried because he may become a source of

220
00:12:41.876 --> 00:12:44.519
resistance because he
hasn't got back to me.

221
00:12:46.516 --> 00:12:49.808
It's really important that we
engage our stakeholders so

222
00:12:49.808 --> 00:12:54.576
we understand who our stakeholders are,
and what their responsibilities are, and

223
00:12:54.576 --> 00:12:57.450
what we actually expect from them.

224
00:12:57.450 --> 00:13:01.785
And when we expect those
activities to happen, as well.

225
00:13:01.785 --> 00:13:03.887
And then what we also need to do is,

226
00:13:03.887 --> 00:13:06.788
it says here delineate
the scope of the change.

227
00:13:06.788 --> 00:13:10.411
But we really need to just
define the scope of the change,

228
00:13:10.411 --> 00:13:14.880
exactly what is going to be changed,
and what shouldn't be changed.

229
00:13:15.940 --> 00:13:20.260
And that's important from
a configuration management perspective.

230
00:13:20.260 --> 00:13:23.410
I need to understand,
when I'm implementing a project,

231
00:13:23.410 --> 00:13:28.230
I need to understand what my
expectations are in terms of scope.

232
00:13:28.230 --> 00:13:30.870
In terms of what hardware
is going to be changed,

233
00:13:30.870 --> 00:13:35.920
what software is going to be changed,
and what is not going to be changed, and

234
00:13:35.920 --> 00:13:38.930
what people are going to be affected.

235
00:13:38.930 --> 00:13:43.210
The last thing that our
support team requires, or

236
00:13:43.210 --> 00:13:46.860
the last thing that our support
team wants, rather, not requires,

237
00:13:46.860 --> 00:13:51.610
is to pick up a phone call or
to pick up a phone from somebody

238
00:13:51.610 --> 00:13:57.210
who has absolutely nothing to do with
the change that went on over the weekend.

239
00:13:57.210 --> 00:14:00.750
Only to find out that it's impacted
them because now, all of a sudden,

240
00:14:00.750 --> 00:14:03.540
they can't get into their financial system

241
00:14:03.540 --> 00:14:06.870
because somebody made a change to
the Windows Server environment.

242
00:14:08.530 --> 00:14:14.760
So we have to ensure that when we
actually define the scope of the change,

243
00:14:14.760 --> 00:14:19.790
that we also sit down with
configuration management and

244
00:14:19.790 --> 00:14:23.880
work out exactly what could be affected.

245
00:14:23.880 --> 00:14:26.890
Look at the relationships
between all of the components.

246
00:14:26.890 --> 00:14:29.620
Look at all the relationships
between all of our services, and

247
00:14:29.620 --> 00:14:34.090
work out exactly what that scope is,
and what could be affected.

248
00:14:34.090 --> 00:14:37.920
Cuz that will also direct our testing,
as well.

249
00:14:37.920 --> 00:14:42.413
And then as part of the formulating
change, we begin the change communication.

250
00:14:43.771 --> 00:14:45.617
And that means we talk to people.

251
00:14:45.617 --> 00:14:48.902
That means we tell them that
something is coming up,

252
00:14:48.902 --> 00:14:53.690
that we're about to implement a change,
that we're going down this road.

253
00:14:53.690 --> 00:14:57.693
And now is the time for your input.

254
00:14:57.693 --> 00:15:00.445
I love what it says on the bottom
right-hand corner, there.

255
00:15:00.445 --> 00:15:04.666
And what it says on the bottom right-hand
corner is the fact that denial and

256
00:15:04.666 --> 00:15:08.040
fear are two primary forms of resistance.

257
00:15:08.040 --> 00:15:08.550
And they are.

258
00:15:09.840 --> 00:15:14.520
If you're frightened of a change,
or you don't understand the change,

259
00:15:14.520 --> 00:15:16.870
then you're more likely to resist.

260
00:15:16.870 --> 00:15:20.190
Which is why we have to ensure
effective communication.

261
00:15:20.190 --> 00:15:23.970
And this is why I said to
you even if you're informed,

262
00:15:23.970 --> 00:15:27.498
I've gotta give you the option
to feed back to me.

263
00:15:27.498 --> 00:15:31.204
Remember in a previous episode, we went
through the emotional cycle of change.

264
00:15:31.204 --> 00:15:34.682
And we looked at the fact that the first
thing that people do is pretend it's not

265
00:15:34.682 --> 00:15:35.271
happening.

266
00:15:35.271 --> 00:15:39.903
If it's a major change, which it is, we're
talking at organizational level here.

267
00:15:39.903 --> 00:15:42.725
If it's a major change,
the first thing that happens is,

268
00:15:42.725 --> 00:15:44.300
well, I'm gonna ignore that.

269
00:15:44.300 --> 00:15:47.785
And if I ignore it for long enough,
[LAUGH] then it's gonna go away.

270
00:15:47.785 --> 00:15:50.563
And that's exactly what we don't want.

271
00:15:50.563 --> 00:15:54.449
We want to be able to
communicate the change.

272
00:15:54.449 --> 00:15:59.980
And ensure that everybody is brought into
that, ensure that everybody is on board.

273
00:15:59.980 --> 00:16:03.181
And that everybody feels
heard because again,

274
00:16:03.181 --> 00:16:08.795
if you don't feel heard then you're more
likely to become a source of resistance.

275
00:16:08.795 --> 00:16:12.323
So we've formulated the change,

276
00:16:12.323 --> 00:16:18.292
then we will define how we
are going to perform the change.

277
00:16:18.292 --> 00:16:20.833
And how we're gonna perform the change,
is well,

278
00:16:20.833 --> 00:16:24.140
is as you see the steps there
in that top left-hand corner.

279
00:16:24.140 --> 00:16:27.270
We're gonna define
the approach first of all, and

280
00:16:27.270 --> 00:16:30.490
then we're going to plan
our stakeholder engagement.

281
00:16:30.490 --> 00:16:33.350
And then we're gonna plan the transition,
so

282
00:16:33.350 --> 00:16:36.910
we've got to understand
what the requirements are.

283
00:16:36.910 --> 00:16:40.430
We've got to define who our resources are,
and

284
00:16:40.430 --> 00:16:45.100
what budget we have,
what our timeline is as well.

285
00:16:45.100 --> 00:16:47.670
And then we've also got to define

286
00:16:47.670 --> 00:16:50.960
how we're going to measure
whether the changes are success.

287
00:16:53.210 --> 00:16:58.075
And then, in our next episode we're gonna
take a look at risk management as well and

288
00:16:58.075 --> 00:16:59.070
risked changes.

289
00:17:00.640 --> 00:17:03.040
But let's just take a quick
look through this for a moment.

290
00:17:04.160 --> 00:17:06.999
We're going to collect our requirements,
well,

291
00:17:06.999 --> 00:17:10.036
we've already looked at in
our previous slide there,

292
00:17:10.036 --> 00:17:14.542
we've looked at all of the things that we
need to do to involve our stakeholders.

293
00:17:14.542 --> 00:17:18.414
And any single one of those stakeholders
could give us some additional

294
00:17:18.414 --> 00:17:21.770
requirements, over and
above the business requirements.

295
00:17:21.770 --> 00:17:25.050
Which is why we talk about
collecting those requirements,

296
00:17:25.050 --> 00:17:27.430
the one thing that we do not want to do,

297
00:17:27.430 --> 00:17:33.620
is ignore any potential requirements
that may have come in as an addition.

298
00:17:33.620 --> 00:17:37.370
Come in as feedback because Ronnie did
actually come back to me with his opinion

299
00:17:37.370 --> 00:17:39.610
on something that I said to him.

300
00:17:39.610 --> 00:17:43.055
And then once we have
all of the feedback and

301
00:17:43.055 --> 00:17:48.796
once we have all of the stakeholder
I was gonna say responsibilities but

302
00:17:48.796 --> 00:17:52.254
it's more about the stakeholder inputs.

303
00:17:52.254 --> 00:17:56.860
Then at that point in time, then what I'm
gonna do is I'm gonna define the actual

304
00:17:56.860 --> 00:18:01.154
physical scope of the change including,
exactly what has to happen when.

305
00:18:01.154 --> 00:18:07.138
It's at this point and time when I
want to see my project Gantt chart,

306
00:18:07.138 --> 00:18:11.059
now, we're in a project
management show and

307
00:18:11.059 --> 00:18:15.824
so I'm hoping that you will
know what a Gantt chart is.

308
00:18:15.824 --> 00:18:18.991
But if you're really,
really unsure as to what a Gantt chart is,

309
00:18:18.991 --> 00:18:21.420
well a Gantt chart is
something that we looked up.

310
00:18:21.420 --> 00:18:26.061
Let me just go back here again and
I will show you this, and

311
00:18:26.061 --> 00:18:29.261
this is actually a Gantt chart, okay?

312
00:18:29.261 --> 00:18:34.210
Now, ordinarily to any project,
then this Gantt chart will

313
00:18:34.210 --> 00:18:38.591
be a series of activities
including our milestones.

314
00:18:38.591 --> 00:18:43.488
And our milestones are the things that we
have to achieve at certain points in time.

315
00:18:43.488 --> 00:18:47.930
So you'll see, we're moving from current
state to future state, that's a timeline.

316
00:18:48.960 --> 00:18:52.070
And so what we're doing on that
Gantt chart is mapping out,

317
00:18:52.070 --> 00:18:56.490
what needs to happen at certain
points during that timeline, and

318
00:18:56.490 --> 00:19:00.860
what we also do is allocate the roles and
responsibilities.

319
00:19:00.860 --> 00:19:05.900
And what we need to do from a project and
a program and a portfolio basis.

320
00:19:05.900 --> 00:19:10.758
Is we need to ensure that we've got the
right resources and the right skills to

321
00:19:10.758 --> 00:19:15.329
be able to perform each of those
activities available to us at that time.

322
00:19:15.329 --> 00:19:20.516
So I mentioned in previous episodes
about the fact that sometimes in

323
00:19:20.516 --> 00:19:26.522
within projects we use what we may call
transient skills and transient teams.

324
00:19:26.522 --> 00:19:29.348
In other words, we'll bring in
contractors with specialist skills.

325
00:19:29.348 --> 00:19:34.220
So, we have to make sure that we
have got the right skills available

326
00:19:34.220 --> 00:19:38.055
at the right time to us to
perform those activities.

327
00:19:38.055 --> 00:19:41.150
And that means we've got to ensure
we've got the right budget, too.

328
00:19:41.150 --> 00:19:44.776
And the right budget may also
mean buying in hardware and

329
00:19:44.776 --> 00:19:47.410
software as well as involving vendors.

330
00:19:49.100 --> 00:19:52.600
And now we've got to define
our success criteria,

331
00:19:52.600 --> 00:19:57.530
it says measure or identify
the measures of benefits realization.

332
00:19:57.530 --> 00:20:00.220
And we start off by defining
our success criteria,

333
00:20:00.220 --> 00:20:04.460
what is this change
project going to achieve?

334
00:20:06.090 --> 00:20:08.590
And then the next question is,
how do we measure it?

335
00:20:10.900 --> 00:20:14.932
So we define the success criteria,
whatever that success criteria may be,

336
00:20:14.932 --> 00:20:15.688
let's say for

337
00:20:15.688 --> 00:20:19.469
instance that we are implementing
a new financial management system.

338
00:20:19.469 --> 00:20:22.468
That is our success criteria, okay so,

339
00:20:22.468 --> 00:20:26.889
how do I know whether we've
implemented it successfully?

340
00:20:26.889 --> 00:20:32.752
That's my benefits realization,
how do I understand that?

341
00:20:32.752 --> 00:20:35.429
I could just say,
well look it's installed, there you go,

342
00:20:35.429 --> 00:20:36.690
is it an icon on the desktop?

343
00:20:36.690 --> 00:20:40.160
Yes it is, right,
well then that's great, isn't it?

344
00:20:40.160 --> 00:20:45.152
No, it's about more than that surely,
right, it's gotta work, but

345
00:20:45.152 --> 00:20:46.664
what does work mean?

346
00:20:46.664 --> 00:20:48.869
Does work mean that it just has to load,
or

347
00:20:48.869 --> 00:20:53.027
if I say well it's gotta work well it's
gotta load when you click on the icon and

348
00:20:53.027 --> 00:20:55.511
there it is it's on
the screen in front of you?

349
00:20:55.511 --> 00:20:57.839
No, no, we should have a set of,

350
00:20:57.839 --> 00:21:02.018
we've already mentioned
CSFs Critical Success Factors.

351
00:21:02.018 --> 00:21:04.725
And underneath those
critical success factors,

352
00:21:04.725 --> 00:21:08.474
see of course we're saying that
the first time really easy, right?

353
00:21:08.474 --> 00:21:12.906
Underneath those CFFs,
we'll stick to the acronym are KPIs,

354
00:21:12.906 --> 00:21:15.088
key performance indicators.

355
00:21:15.088 --> 00:21:20.076
And I have to achieve certain levels
within my KPIs to denote whether I have

356
00:21:20.076 --> 00:21:22.820
achieved my critical success factors.

357
00:21:23.830 --> 00:21:31.600
So if my KPIs are such that maybe I
have to ensure that all invoices are,

358
00:21:31.600 --> 00:21:35.930
submitted to the vendors within this
new financial management system,

359
00:21:35.930 --> 00:21:40.660
all invoices are submitted to the vendors
within ten days of being input.

360
00:21:40.660 --> 00:21:45.360
And then,
another KPI may be that all reports

361
00:21:45.360 --> 00:21:50.530
are produced within, I don't know,
ten minutes of being requested.

362
00:21:50.530 --> 00:21:54.742
And so
we're gonna have a set of KPIs depending

363
00:21:54.742 --> 00:21:58.738
on what it is that service
is supposed to do.

364
00:21:58.738 --> 00:22:03.355
And financial management could be anything
it could be making sure that we pay

365
00:22:03.355 --> 00:22:05.352
everybody on time for instance.

366
00:22:05.352 --> 00:22:11.990
Your KPIs will tell you whether you
are achieving success of any change.

367
00:22:11.990 --> 00:22:17.730
But remember what I said in a previous
episode, you don't just measure your KPIs,

368
00:22:17.730 --> 00:22:23.065
your benefits realization the minute
that you have implemented something.

369
00:22:23.065 --> 00:22:27.582
Cuz that's really not gonna tell you all
that much, and the first sort of day or

370
00:22:27.582 --> 00:22:32.600
two that you implement something, it's not
gonna get used, to be perfectly honest.

371
00:22:32.600 --> 00:22:37.326
It's just gonna cause more negative
impact than positive impact immediately.

372
00:22:37.326 --> 00:22:43.146
And so, you've got to ensure that yes,
you've measured implementation but

373
00:22:43.146 --> 00:22:46.586
you measure your KPIs at
regular intervals for

374
00:22:46.586 --> 00:22:50.553
a set period of time,
before you can then demonstrate

375
00:22:50.553 --> 00:22:55.257
that a change has actually achieved
what it set out to achieve.

376
00:22:57.405 --> 00:23:00.870
So here we're planing our
approach to implement

377
00:23:00.870 --> 00:23:05.611
in the change then we've got to
plan what we're going to measure.

378
00:23:05.611 --> 00:23:08.877
We need to know what we're
supposed to be achieving and

379
00:23:08.877 --> 00:23:11.008
what we are setting out to achieve.

380
00:23:11.008 --> 00:23:14.359
And we need to know how it's going
to be measured and we need to

381
00:23:14.359 --> 00:23:18.462
know that right now because this is
how we build that particular service.

382
00:23:18.462 --> 00:23:22.971
We will build it so that it can
deliver our report within ten minutes,

383
00:23:22.971 --> 00:23:24.779
if that's one of our KPIs.

384
00:23:24.779 --> 00:23:28.839
We will deliver it so that it can
produce an invoice within ten days,

385
00:23:28.839 --> 00:23:30.850
if that's one of the KPIs.

386
00:23:30.850 --> 00:23:35.940
We'll deliver it so that it can pay people
on time, if that's one of the KPIs.

387
00:23:37.240 --> 00:23:42.860
We're not going to deliver an additional
functionality that's not part of the KPIs,

388
00:23:42.860 --> 00:23:45.459
and therefore is not part of
the benefits realization.

389
00:23:46.800 --> 00:23:51.057
So this is where we set all of this out,
and

390
00:23:51.057 --> 00:23:59.464
then what we're also going to do is we're
going to perform some risk management.

391
00:23:59.464 --> 00:24:03.148
Now, I'm not gonna look at risk
management right now, okay,

392
00:24:03.148 --> 00:24:07.737
what I'm going to do is we're gonna
come back again, and in another episode,

393
00:24:07.737 --> 00:24:12.500
our next episode, we're going to look
specifically at risk management.

394
00:24:12.500 --> 00:24:17.930
And then at actually closing
the change after we have implemented.

395
00:24:17.930 --> 00:24:19.190
>> All right Jo, thank you for

396
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:22.830
helping us once again and taking a look
at this idea of performing the change.

397
00:24:22.830 --> 00:24:26.650
Lot of times, it's very easy to think that
it's gonna be something that we don't have

398
00:24:26.650 --> 00:24:30.060
to think about, but
putting this to at least in our mind.

399
00:24:30.060 --> 00:24:33.123
Getting everything set up for
understanding that we have to plan,

400
00:24:33.123 --> 00:24:35.155
formulate, do everything that we need to.

401
00:24:35.155 --> 00:24:37.928
To prepare for this because there
are many different resistances and

402
00:24:37.928 --> 00:24:39.490
factors that are out there.

403
00:24:39.490 --> 00:24:40.930
Is really gonna be key and

404
00:24:40.930 --> 00:24:43.700
now we also have to take a look at
the idea of risk that are involved too.

405
00:24:43.700 --> 00:24:48.043
But that is for another episode then,
signing off for ITProTV,

406
00:24:48.043 --> 00:24:51.022
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

407
00:24:51.022 --> 00:24:52.039
>> Stay tuned right here for

408
00:24:52.039 --> 00:24:54.175
more organizational change
management episodes.
